prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But your whispers hide in corners where shadows play,
Between heartbeats and forgotten dreams you linger,
A ghost of certainty in a world gone gray.

How often have I turned away from your face,
Pretending not to hear when you called my name?
Comfort found in lies that fit like second skin,
While you stand naked, unadorned, without shame.

If I listen now, will you still speak to me?
After years of silence, of choosing deafness instead?
Your patience terrifies me more than your judgment,
Your constancy more damning than words unsaid.

So I cup my hands around my ears today,
And lean into the void where your voice resides.
Teach me again the language I have forgotten,
The truth of being true when nothing else abides.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears have grown deaf from convenience,
And my tongue has learned the taste of sweeter things.
I have become a collector of comfortable fictions,
Hoarding them like treasures against the winter of reality.

Truth! You stand at my doorway, patient as stone,
While I pretend not to hear your knocking.
What strange creatures we are, to fear the very thing
That might set us free from our elegant prisons.

If I were to listen now, what would you say?
Would you speak of the person I've become,
Or the one I've failed to be?
Would you illuminate the shadows I've cultivated,
Or simply stand as witness to my careful evasions?

Perhaps today I will crack open the window,
Just enough to let your whisper in.
Perhaps today I will practice the forgotten art
Of hearing before speaking, of knowing before claiming,
Of being before seeming.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But habits are hard-formed and harder broken,
Like rivers carving canyons through resistant stone,
Or stars burning patterns into the night's dark token.

I've practiced selective deafness when you approach,
Pretended sleep when your footsteps echo near.
Yet somehow your voice penetrates my fortress walls,
A persistent drumbeat I cannot help but hear.

What strange bargain is this between us?
You, patient as mountains; me, fleeting as mist.
You offer liberation through your steady gaze,
While I offer only resistance and a clenched fist.

Perhaps the habit worth forming isn't speaking,
But the discipline of silence, the courage to hear,
To sit with discomfort as you unfold your message,
To welcome you not with dread, but without fear.

So speak, Truth, I am listening at last.
My ears are open, my defenses at rest.
I cannot promise I'll always heed your wisdom,
But today, at least, I welcome you as my guest.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But habits form in silence, in the spaces between intention.
I have become skilled at drowning your voice
Beneath the cacophony of what I wish to believe.

You do not shout to be heard above the din.
You simply wait, eternal as mountains,
For the moment when exhaustion quiets my mind
And I can no longer sustain the weight of illusion.

How strange that I fear you, when you offer freedom.
How peculiar that I run from you, when you promise peace.
I have mistaken comfort for happiness,
And confusion for complexity.

Perhaps truth-speaking begins with truth-hearing,
With cupped hands around alert ears,
With the courage to sit in the discomfort
Of recognizing myself as I truly am.

So I will practice this habit of listening,
Of creating space where your voice might echo.
And perhaps, in time, my own voice will align with yours,
And I will speak truth because I have learned to hear it.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears have grown selective in these noisy times.
I tune to frequencies of comfort and convenience,
While you broadcast on channels I've long abandoned.

You are the unwelcome guest at midnight,
Knocking when I've settled into dreams of my own making.
You are the mirror I turn to face the wall,
The letter I leave unopened on the table.

What would happen if I tuned my instrument to your pitch?
If I cleared the dust from your neglected altar?
Would your voice be thunder or whisper?
Would you condemn or simply witness?

Perhaps the speaking comes only after listening,
After years of apprenticeship to your subtle teachings.
Perhaps I cannot voice what I have not first heard,
Cannot give what I refuse to receive.

So today I practice this radical listening,
This revolutionary act of attention.
I cup my hands around my ears and lean toward your voice,
Preparing my tongue for truths it has never spoken.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
TRUTH'S WHISPER

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Through the cacophony of lies that daily drift by,
Like autumn leaves on winds of convenient deception.

You hide in plain sight, a diamond among rhinestones,
While I strain to hear your whisper beneath
The thunderous applause for comfortable falsehoods.

How can I voice what I've not learned to hear?
My tongue grows heavy with borrowed opinions,
My ears selective in their attention.

So I sit in silence, unlearning distraction,
Training my heart to recognize your rhythm,
Your steady pulse beneath the world's fever.

For truth cannot be spoken by lips
That have not first been humbled to listen,
To receive before they give, to know before they tell.

I shall speak you, Truth, only when
Your voice becomes more familiar to me
Than my own cherished illusions.

LISTENING FOR TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how rarely I pause to hear your voice—
That clear bell ringing in the chambers of conscience.

My ears are filled with the market's clamor,
With siren songs of what I wish to believe,
With echoes of my own voice bouncing back.

You are patient, Truth, waiting in the silence
Between heartbeats, between breaths,
Between the lines of stories I tell myself.

How can I claim to speak what I refuse to hear?
How can I offer others what I deny myself?
The medicine I will not swallow?

So I practice this discipline of listening—
Stripping away layers of pretense,
Sitting naked before your mirror.

Only then, humbled and attentive,
Might my tongue be worthy of your weight,
My voice a vessel for your light.

THE LISTENER'S VOW

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But listening requires courage I often lack,
And silence I rarely grant myself.

You arrive uninvited at inconvenient hours,
Disturbing carefully constructed narratives,
Shaking foundations I've spent years cementing.

You speak in languages I pretend not to understand—
In the eyes of strangers who see through me,
In the quiet moments when masks slip away.

I have been a poor student of your teachings,
Preferring the comfort of half-truths,
The safety of selective hearing.

Yet you persist, patient teacher,
Waiting for me to exhaust my excuses,
To empty my cup of preconceptions.

So I vow to practice this sacred listening,
To create space where you might dwell,
To become worthy of your sharp-edged gift.

TRUTH'S APPRENTICE

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I can quiet the carnival of my mind long enough
To hear your footsteps approaching.

You are not what I expected—
Neither gentle nor cruel, neither simple
Nor impossibly complex.

You simply are, indifferent to my preferences,
Unmoved by my protests, unchanged
By my desperate revisions.

I have spent years as a ventriloquist,
Throwing my voice into wooden figures
That look like truth but cannot bleed.

Now I apprentice myself to silence,
To the discipline of open hands,
To the practice of undefended listening.

For what use is a mouth that speaks
Without ears that have learned to discern
Between the echo and the source?

THE LISTENING PATH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I can still the restless waters of my mind
To reflect your face without distortion.

How often I have claimed to be your messenger
While stuffing cotton in my ears,
Shouting to drown out your inconvenient whispers.

I have mistaken my own voice for yours,
My own desires for your directions,
My own fears for your warnings.

Forgive me this arrogance of speech
Before the humility of listening,
This harvest before the patient planting.

I begin again as a student of silence,
Learning to distinguish your voice
From the thousand imposters that mimic your tone.

Only then, when I have earned the right
Through the long apprenticeship of listening,
Will I dare to speak your name.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But silence has become my trusted friend,
While your whispers fade like morning dew.

In corners of my mind where shadows grow,
I've built a fortress against your light,
Pretending not to see what I already know.

How strange that I should fear your simple face,
When lies require such elaborate disguise,
And falsehoods leave the soul in disarray.

So let me tune my ears to hear again,
The steady rhythm of your honest voice,
Though it may bring both clarity and pain.

For what is growth but shedding comfortable skins?
What is wisdom but embracing what is real?
The journey toward you is where living begins.

Truth! I shall speak you when I've learned to listen,
When I've stilled the noise that drowns your call,
And in that sacred silence, we both shall glisten.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears have grown selective with age,
Filtering your voice through walls of convenience.

You stand naked in the garden of perception,
While I clothe you in fabrics of my choosing,
Pretending the garments were always yours.

How often have I claimed to seek your face,
Only to turn away when your reflection
Revealed the parts of me I wished to erase?

You are the unwelcome guest at midnight,
Knocking when I've settled into comfortable dreams,
Demanding entrance with uncompromising light.

Yet in your absence, I wander lost,
A traveler without compass or north star,
Paying freedom's highest cost.

So let me practice the discipline of listening,
Of sitting in the discomfort of your presence,
Until speaking you becomes as natural as breathing.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But the world has taught me selective deafness,
And my tongue has learned the art of bending.

In childhood, you were simple as sunrise,
Clear as water cupped in innocent hands.
When did complexity cloud your skies?

You hide in plain sight, among ordinary things:
In the mirror's unforgiving morning light,
In the silence after the telephone rings.

Society celebrates those who dance around you,
Who craft beautiful approximations of your form,
While shunning those who dare speak you through.

Yet what power resides in your utterance!
What freedom in surrendering to your weight!
What healing in your persistent utterance!

So I shall train my ears to detect your frequency,
Amid the static noise of convenient half-truths,
And my voice shall become your sanctuary.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But we've grown estranged in these strange times,
When facts bend like willows in political winds.

You are not what I was taught to believe—
A fixed and rigid monument of stone—
But a living river that continues to cleave

New pathways through the landscape of thought.
You demand not blind allegiance or faith,
But the courage to question what I've been taught.

How frightening to stand before your mirror,
To see reflected both beauty and flaw,
To recognize both the saint and the sinner.

Yet in this vulnerable exposure lies strength,
In this radical honesty, liberation,
In this difficult practice, at length—

A self that no longer hides from its shadow,
A voice that rings with authentic tone,
A life where listening and speaking both follow

The thread of what is, not what I wish to be.
Truth! I shall speak you when I've learned to listen,
And in that listening, finally be free.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears have grown calloused from convenient lies,
Small deceptions piled like stones along my path.

You arrive uninvited at the worst moments—
During comfortable conversations and practiced smiles,
When I've nearly convinced myself of my own illusions.

Why must you be so uncompromising?
Why can't you bend just slightly to accommodate
The fragile architectures of human relationships?

And yet, without you, what are we but shadows?
Without your light, how can we claim to see?
Without your foundation, what can we truly build?

Perhaps the listening is itself the practice—
The daily meditation of removing filters,
Of clearing channels long clogged with fear.

So I shall sit in silence and attune myself
To your frequency, however uncomfortable,
Until speaking you becomes an act of love,
Not just for what is, but for what could be
When we align ourselves with what is real.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
TRUTH'S WHISPER

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how seldom I've stilled my mind to hear your voice.
The clamor of convenience drowns your whispers,
As I build fortresses of comfort with bricks of denial.

You wait patiently in the corners of consciousness,
Neither forcing entry nor fleeing when ignored.
A faithful companion whose loyalty I've spurned
For the fleeting embrace of prettier lies.

If I were to cultivate silence as a garden,
Would your seeds take root in the fertile soil of my attention?
Perhaps then your vines might climb the trellis of my tongue,
And blossom into words that mirror what is real.

I commit now to this listening pilgrimage,
To bend my ear to the ground where your currents flow.
For truth unheard remains truth still,
But truth unspoken leaves the world unchanged.

LISTENING FOR TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears are filled with the static of desire,
And my mouth shapes words before wisdom arrives.
I have become an echo chamber of convenient beliefs.

How does one tune the frequency of attention
To catch your broadcast through the noise?
You speak in whispers while falsehood shouts,
Yet your quiet persistence outlasts all temporary roars.

I've mistaken volume for veracity,
Confused repetition with revelation.
Now I seek to unlearn these errors,
To create space where your voice might resonate.

Perhaps truth is not something to be captured
But a relationship to be cultivated—
A daily practice of removing veils,
Of standing naked before what is.

So I shall listen first, with humility as my guide,
And only then, when you have filled me completely,
Will I dare to become your vessel, your voice,
Your faithful servant in a world starved for honesty.

THE LISTENER'S OATH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
This I vow beneath the watchful stars.
For too long I've filled silence with convenient noise,
Drowning your whispers with my fearful chorus.

You do not announce yourself with trumpets,
Nor arrive dressed in certainty's bold colors.
You come as question, as doubt, as the pause
Between what I wish and what simply is.

To speak you requires first the courage to hear you—
To feel the tremor when foundations shift,
To welcome the collapse of cherished illusions,
To stand in the rubble of what I thought I knew.

I am learning to listen with my whole being:
Ears attuned to nuance, mind open to revision,
Heart willing to break for your sake,
Hands ready to build anew from your blueprints.

So let this be my practice: silence before speech,
Reception before proclamation,
Humility before certainty—
For truth speaks through those who first learn to listen.

TRUTH'S APPRENTICE

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But listening is an art I've scarcely practiced.
My ears, so full of what I wish to hear,
Have become selective gatekeepers of reality.

You reside in uncomfortable silences,
In the spaces between what I project and what returns.
You hide in plain sight, unadorned and patient,
Waiting for the moment when I exhaust my narratives.

I've been a poor apprentice to your craft—
Quick to claim your mantle, slow to earn it.
Perhaps wisdom begins with this admission:
That I cannot speak what I refuse to hear.

So I surrender now my need to fill the void,
To interpret before understanding, to answer before questioning.
I commit to the discipline of attentive silence,
To becoming empty enough to be filled by you.

And when you've saturated every fiber of my being,
When your reality has replaced my illusions,
Only then might my tongue be worthy
To form the syllables of your sacred name.

THE HABIT OF TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But habits form slowly, through repetition and return.
I must train my ears like a musician tunes an instrument,
Calibrating to your frequency amid cacophony.

You reveal yourself in layers, not all at once—
A gradual unveiling that requires patience,
A willingness to sit with discomfort,
To befriend uncertainty as my teacher.

The world rewards those who speak with confidence,
Not those who pause to question their knowing.
Yet what authority have I to proclaim
What I have not deeply heard and held?

So I shall practice this radical listening—
In conversations where I yearn to interject,
In moments when certainty seems within reach,
In the face of evidence that challenges my beliefs.

And perhaps, through this daily devotion,
This humble attendance to what is,
My voice might eventually become worthy
Of being truth's faithful messenger rather than its distortion.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
TRUTH'S WHISPER

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how seldom I pause to hear your steady breath,
Beneath the clamor of desire and fear that drowns you.
You whisper while the world shouts its certainties.

I have sought you in libraries and cathedrals,
In the mouths of prophets and pages of philosophy,
Only to find you waiting in the silence between heartbeats,
Patient as stone, fluid as water finding its level.

To speak truth requires first the courage to hear it—
To cup one's ears against the convenient narratives
We tell ourselves to soften life's jagged edges.
To listen for truth is to stand naked before mirrors that never lie.

So I practice this listening like a forgotten language,
Tongue-tied and stumbling, but persistent in my pursuit.
For what is more sacred than this communion?
Truth, I shall speak you, but first—I must learn to listen.

THE LISTENER'S OATH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears are often filled with sweeter songs—
Lullabies of self-deception, anthems of ego,
The comforting static of half-believed lies.

How can I channel your voice through these reluctant lips
When I've spent years building walls against your echo?
You arrive uninvited at midnight conversations,
Tapping at windows I've painted over with dreams.

To listen for truth is to excavate the self,
Digging past layers of want and should-have-been,
Unearthing bones of authentic experience
Buried beneath sediment of expectation.

I promise to practice this discipline of silence,
To create space where your whispers might land,
To honor the covenant between speaker and spoken,
For truth without listening is just another noise in the void.

So I shall listen, and in listening, learn to speak you.

RECIPROCITY

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But we've grown distant, like old friends who rarely call.
I chase echoes of you through crowded streets,
Glimpse your shadow in passing reflections.

The world has taught me to filter and soften,
To round your edges until you fit neatly in conversation.
I've learned to dress you in acceptable fabrics,
Diluting your potency with qualifiers and maybes.

Yet still you persist, stubborn as sunrise,
Breaking through cracks in my careful constructions.
You demand attention with your inconvenient clarity,
Shining light on corners I've left unexamined.

Perhaps truth is not something we speak at all,
But a conversation we enter with open hands,
A dance of giving and receiving, listening and responding,
A sacred exchange between the world as it is and as we see it.

So I shall listen more deeply, that I might speak more truly.

THE HABIT OF TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But habits form slowly, through daily practice and devotion.
I have been trained in the art of selective hearing,
Filtering reality through sieves of comfort and convenience.

How strange that we call you absolute yet treat you as optional,
Invoking your name while avoiding your gaze.
We build temples to your virtue while worshipping
At the more accessible altars of what we wish to believe.

To listen for truth requires a particular kind of courage—
The willingness to stand corrected, to be unmade and remade,
To acknowledge that certainty is often the first disguise of ignorance,
And that wisdom begins where defensiveness ends.

So I shall cultivate this habit of listening,
Turn down the volume on my own internal monologue,
Create silence where your voice might find purchase.
For only in truly hearing can I hope to honestly speak.

TRUTH'S BARGAIN

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A conditional promise, a bargain struck between us.
As if truth were a currency we trade in conversation,
Receiving only as much as we're willing to hear.

How often I've claimed to be your faithful messenger
While plugging my ears to your uncomfortable verses.
I've mistaken my own voice for yours, projecting
My desires onto your blank and neutral canvas.

Yet you remain, patient beyond measure,
Neither offended by rejection nor flattered by attention.
You simply are—persistent as gravity,
Indifferent to whether we acknowledge your pull.

Perhaps this is the lesson you've waited to teach me:
That speaking and listening are not separate actions
But a single practice of presence and attention,
A continuous circle of receiving and giving.

So I shall dissolve the bargain and its conditions.
Truth, I shall listen, and in that listening, become your voice.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
TRUTH SPEAKER

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how often do I close my ears to your whispered warnings?
You knock at dawn when my dreams still cloud judgment,
You tap at dusk when my weary heart seeks comfort in lies.

To speak truth requires first the courage to hear it—
The mirror's unflinching gaze, the friend's unwelcome counsel,
The silent voice that rises from within when all is quiet.
I cannot give what I refuse to receive.

So I practice the art of listening:
To the spaces between heartbeats,
To the pauses between certainties,
To the questions beneath my answers.

Only then, when truth has made its home in me,
When I have welcomed it like an old friend,
Might my tongue form words worthy of its name,
Might I become a vessel for what endures.

LISTENING RITUAL

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But the listening itself is a discipline I have yet to master.
Each morning I cup my hands around silence,
Hoping to catch your elusive whisper.

You hide in plain sight—
In the child's unfiltered question,
In the body's quiet protest against what the mind demands,
In the tears that come without permission.

I have spoken many words in your name
That were merely echoes of my own wanting,
Mistaking conviction for clarity,
Mistaking volume for veracity.

Perhaps truth is not a declaration but a conversation,
A sacred dialogue between what is and what could be.
I vow to listen before I speak,
To empty myself of certainty,
To make of my life a vessel
Where you might dwell without distortion.

THE HABIT OF TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But habits form slowly, like water carving stone,
And I have been deaf too long to your persistent calling.

How many times have you knocked at my door
While I turned up the volume on more pleasant sounds?
How often have you written your message in the stars
While I kept my eyes fixed firmly on the ground?

Truth demands a particular kind of courage—
Not the bravery of battle but the strength to stand still,
To create space where your voice might echo,
To resist the urge to fill silence with comfortable noise.

I am learning to listen with more than my ears:
With the cells of my body, with the wounds of my past,
With the questions that keep me awake at night.

Speak to me, Truth, even when it hurts.
I am developing the habit of your company,
Slowly becoming worthy of your trust.

TRUTH'S APPRENTICE

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But listening is an art I've neglected far too long.
I've been a merchant of convenient half-truths,
A curator of comfortable illusions.

You do not arrive dressed in certainty,
But in the humble garments of doubt.
You speak not in thunderous declarations
But in the gentle questioning of assumptions.

I pledge to become your apprentice:
To sit in the workshop of silence,
To learn the grammar of honesty,
To study the texture of what is real.

Each day I will practice discernment—
Separating the wheat of authenticity
From the chaff of self-deception.

And perhaps one day, after years of listening,
My voice might become worthy of your name,
My words might carry the weight of what endures,
And I might speak you, Truth, with the clarity
Of one who has learned to listen well.

THE LISTENER'S VOW

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I can quiet the clamor of my own desires,
If I can silence the chorus of convenient excuses,
If I can still the trembling of my fear.

You are not found in the marketplace of opinions,
Nor in the temple of rigid certainties.
You dwell in the wilderness between what I know
And what I have yet to discover.

To listen for truth requires patience:
The willingness to sit with discomfort,
To hold contradictions without rushing to resolve them,
To admit when the map I've drawn no longer matches the territory.

I vow to become a student of listening—
To tune my ear to the frequency of what's real,
To distinguish between the voice of truth
And the seductive whispers of what I wish were true.

Only then, humbled by listening,
Might I dare to speak in your name.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender heart and soul.
Like waves that crash against the sea,
Your presence makes me whole.

The stars, though bright in midnight sky,
Cannot compare to your sweet light.
For in your gaze, I come alive,
A phoenix rising through the night.

What treasures could this world contain
That match the wealth of your embrace?
Gold turns to dust, fame proves in vain,
Beside the wonder of your face.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I traverse the darkest path.
For you alone have set me free,
A freedom worth the aftermath.

So take my hand and hold it tight,
For nothing less will ever do.
You are my day, my guiding light,
My heart beats only, dear, for you.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could ever fill this hollow space
Where once a heart beat steadily,
Now quickens at your gentle grace.

I've wandered through the wilderness,
Searched mountain peaks and valley floors,
Yet found no cure for loneliness
Until you opened up your doors.

The universe, in all its might,
Created stars and galaxies,
But none shine with such pure delight
As when your smile is aimed at me.

What use are riches, fame or gold?
What purpose serve these mortal things?
When in your arms, I've found the hold
That gives my earthbound soul its wings.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have learned what it means
To truly live, to truly see
Beyond the veil of shallow dreams.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have crossed the raging sea,
Traversed the desert's burning sand,
And climbed tall mountains, hand in hand.

The moon may pull the tides away,
The sun may set at close of day,
But my devotion stands unmoved,
By time and distance only proved.

What are the treasures of this earth?
Gold, silver, gems of countless worth?
They pale beside your gentle smile,
That makes each struggle seem worthwhile.

The birds may sing of joy and spring,
The poets of the love they bring,
But none could capture in their art
The depths you've reached within my heart.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have known what love could be—
A force that shapes the very soul,
Breaks us apart, then makes us whole.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender all I am.
Like ancient trees with roots so deep,
My love stands firm where others ran.

The world may offer golden crowns,
And praise that echoes through the years,
But I would trade these hollow sounds
For just one whisper in my ears.

What is the wealth of kings to me?
What glory could compare to this?
The quiet joy of simply being
Held in the circle of your bliss.

Time may erode the tallest peak,
And oceans swallow continents,
Yet in your eyes, I find the peace
That makes all other quests relent.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have learned to truly see
That in this vast, unending space,
I've found my home in your embrace.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have opened rusted doors
That guarded chambers deep within
Where no one dared to tread before.

The universe, in all its might,
Has scattered wonders far and wide,
Yet none compare to that first night
When fear and hope stood side by side.

What kingdoms rise and fall like waves
Upon the shores of human time?
While we, in silent moments, save
Eternities in glances, rhymes.

The scholars speak of cosmic dust,
Of how we're made of dying stars,
But they've not felt this sacred trust
That heals our deepest, oldest scars.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have learned what it means to fall,
To shatter like glass, then carefully
Reassemble, stronger after all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would my heart ever truly beat,
Like stars that dance across the sea,
Or whispers where two worlds meet.

Your touch, a gentle summer rain,
Your voice, a melody divine,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer,
When the world stood still,
Shimmering heat rising
O'er valley and hill.

Cicadas sang loudly
Their ancient refrain,
As shadows grew shorter
On the sun-dappled plain.

Wildflowers nodded
In the languorous breeze,
While birds sought their refuge
In the shade of the trees.

Time seemed suspended
In amber and gold,
As stories of seasons
In silence unfold.

The creek barely whispered,
Its waters ran low,
Reflecting the heavens
In its gentle flow.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When dreams drift and weave,
Between what is present
And what we perceive.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And the blazing sun reigned,
Casting fire upon meadows
Where once cool dew remained.

The earth cracked and thirsted,
As if crying for rain,
While memories of springtime
Grew distant and faint.

I wandered alone then,
Through fields scorched and dry,
Where once lovers had whispered
'Neath a gentler sky.

The ghosts of past seasons
Danced just out of reach,
Like fragments of letters
On a wind-scattered beach.

In this merciless brightness,
In this moment suspended,
I found strange revelation
Where hope and grief blended.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And in that harsh light,
I glimpsed hidden truths
That hide in the night.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When the clock forgot time,
And the world held its breath
In a moment sublime.

The lake lay like mirror,
Not a ripple in sight,
As if nature had paused
In her endless flight.

Butterflies hovered
Over nectar-rich blooms,
Their wings catching sunlight
Like nature's looms.

I sat 'neath an oak tree,
Centuries old and wise,
Its branches reaching upward
To touch azure skies.

In this perfect stillness,
In this golden hour,
I felt life's true meaning
In each perfect flower.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When my soul broke free,
And danced with the present,
As it was meant to be.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When nightmares awoke,
The sun burned like fury
Through billows of smoke.

The forest stood burning,
Ancient trees turned to ash,
As mankind's indifference
Met nature's backlash.

Red embers flew skyward
Like vengeful bright stars,
While creatures fled homelands
Now scarred with deep chars.

I watched from the hillside,
Helpless, alone,
As paradise withered
And beauty was gone.

Yet even in darkness,
In destruction's wake,
Seeds waited in ashes
New life to partake.

'Twas noontide of summer,
A lesson in fire,
Of endings and beginnings
Rising ever higher.

'Twas noontide of summer,
In a long-ago year,
When childhood seemed endless
And troubles not near.

The ice cream truck's jingle,
A siren's sweet call,
As we raced down the sidewalk,
Bare feet and all.

The sprinkler's cool rainbow
Arced over green lawn,
While screen doors slammed shut
From dusk until dawn.

Fireflies in jars served
As night-lights so bright,
Before parents' soft voices
Bid final goodnight.

Those innocent moments,
Now seen through time's veil,
Grow sweeter in memory
As real details fail.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When I was but small,
Now cherished more deeply
Than I knew at all.

The bees hummed their chorus
In lavender fields,
Drunk on the nectar
That each blossom yields.

I wandered alone
Through this sun-drenched domain,
My thoughts like the clouds—
Ever-changing, arcane.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When life's fullness peaks,
And the soul finds its voice
In the silence it seeks.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When ghosts walk unseen,
Slipping through sunlight
Where darkness had been.

The clock tower struck twelve,
Its toll heavy, deep,
Waking memories long
Buried in sleep.

The graveyard of childhood
Lay scorched in the heat,
Where innocence died
And time knew defeat.

I stood at the crossroads
Of what was and is,
Feeling the weight
Of all I now miss.

The cicadas screamed warnings
Of summers to come,
Of climate's fierce vengeance,

'Twas noontide of summer,
The world at its peak,
Before the long fall

'Twas noontide of summer,

The cosmos vibrated
With solstice song,
As ancestors whispered
Of days growing long.

The veil between worlds
Grew gossamer thin,
Allowing old magic
To seep slowly in.

I drank from the chalice
Of midsummer's light,
Felt power surge through me,
A glorious might.

The trees bent to listen
To secrets I spoke,
As ancient connections
Within me awoke.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When time stands apart,
And the universe writes
Its truths on the heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:

The cicadas' loud singing,

The oak tree's deep shadow

A refuge from sun where cool breezes still played.
While butterflies drifted
On currents that lifted
Their delicate wings through the light and the shade.

I lay there half-dreaming,
With memories streaming
Like ribbons of light through the haze of my mind.
The past and the present
Both equally pleasant,
As summer's sweet magic left worries behind.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When the world stood still,
Suspended in golden light.
The sun, a merciless sovereign,
Reigned from its zenith throne,
Casting no shadows to hide beneath.

The earth exhaled heat,
Rising in visible waves,
Distorting the distant hills.
Cicadas screamed their defiance,
A chorus of ancient voices,
Telling tales of summers past.

I wandered alone,
A solitary pilgrim,
Seeking solace from the burning sky.
My thoughts melted like wax,
Forming new patterns,
Shapes I couldn't recognize.

In this crucible of light,
I found myself transformed,
A phoenix born of summer's flame.
'Twas noontide of summer,
And I was forever changed.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And the blazing sun hung
Like a molten medallion
In the breathless blue expanse.

Time slowed to honey-drip pace,
As drowsy bees performed
Their pollen-laden waltz
Among nodding wildflowers.

The ancient oak whispered secrets
To none but itself,
Its leaves barely stirring
In the thick, still air.

Somewhere distant, a creek laughed,
Its cool voice a memory
Of spring's gentle promise,
Now dried to a trickle.

I pressed my back to warm earth,
Feeling its steady pulse beneath me,
And surrendered to summer's embrace—
Neither past nor future existed,
Only this perfect, endless moment
When the world paused at its zenith,
And breathed with me as one.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When shadows grow short
And the sun's fierce embrace
Holds the world in its court.

The lake lies unmoving,
A mirror of blue,
Reflecting the heavens
In crystalline view.

No whisper of wind
Disturbs the still trees,
No rustle of leaves,
No wandering breeze.

Time seems to stand frozen,
Like insects in amber,
As heat waves rise dancing
In shimmering clamor.

I sit by the water,
Half-dreaming, half-wake,
As memories and visions
Like ripples do break.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When past meets the now,
When the veil grows so thin
That the gods might allow
A glimpse of forever
In this moment somehow.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When the world held its breath,
And the sun's molten fingers
Caressed the parched earth.

The horizon shimmered,
A mirage of dreams,
Where reality melted
Into what might have been.

Dust devils danced wildly,
Ephemeral ghosts,
Spinning tales of the desert
To invisible hosts.

In the shade of a cypress,
Ancient and wise,
I watched as the moments
Unfolded like sighs.

A lizard moved slowly
Across sun-baked stone,
Its primitive rhythm
Matched time's languid tone.

No future existed,
No past could remain,
Just this eternal present,
This absence of pain.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When I finally knew,
That heaven exists
In the simplest of truths.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text:
This anger burns deep within,
A smoldering coal in my chest.
It feeds on memories of yesterday,
On words that should have been left unsaid.

I carry it like a faithful pet,
Nurtured by sleepless nights and bitter tears.
It colors my world in shades of red,
Distorting joy into nameless fears.

But anger is a double-edged sword,
Cutting the one who wields it most.
I'm learning to release its fiery grip,
To let the embers cool to ghost.

For what is rage but love inverted,
Passion twisted out of shape?
I'll transform this burning anger
Into strength that helps me escape.

This anger burns deep within,
But I am deeper still than flame.
I am the ocean to this spark,
Vast enough to quench my pain.

This anger burns deep within,
A dragon coiled around my heart.
Scales of resentment, claws of pain,
Tearing my insides apart.

It whispers tales of vengeance sweet,
Of justice never served.
Of battles lost and wounds received,
Of love that never curved.

I've fed this beast for far too long,
With memories dipped in bile.
Each grudge a morsel, each slight a feast,
Growing stronger all the while.

But dragons, too, must hibernate,
And fires eventually dim.
I seek the courage to face this beast,
To look it in the eye and swim

Beneath the flames, beyond the rage,
To find the hurt child there.
This anger burns deep within,
But healing waits beneath despair.

This anger burns deep within,
Like magma beneath the earth's thin crust.
A primal force, ancient and raw,
Waiting to erupt in disgust.

Inherited from ancestors' blood,
Passed down through generations untold.
A righteous flame against injustice,
Against stories that went unsold.

I will not apologize for this fire,
That illuminates what others ignore.
The comfortable silence of privilege,
The wounds that lie at history's core.

This anger burns deep within,
Not to destroy but to forge anew.
To melt down systems built on lies,
And hammer out something true.

So let it burn, this sacred rage,
Let it transform, not consume.
For in its heat, a world reborn,
May finally find room to bloom.

This anger burns deep within,
A quiet, constant companion.
Neither friend nor foe but something else—
A teacher wrapped in thorns.

It speaks in languages of fire,
In clenched jaws and trembling hands.
In midnight thoughts that spiral down,
To places no one understands.

I've tried to drown it, starve it out,
To reason with its hungry flame.
To meditate it into silence,
To give this nameless thing a name.

But perhaps I've misunderstood
This energy that pulses through.
Perhaps it's not a demon haunting,
But a guard dog, loyal and true.

This anger burns deep within,
A signal flare from my soul's depths.
Warning of boundaries crossed,
Of needs unmet, of stolen breaths.

This anger burns deep within,
A winter sun that gives no warmth.
Illuminating landscapes barren,
Of what once was, what could have been.

It seeps into my marrow slow,
Replacing blood with kerosene.
Until each thought strikes like a match,
Against the roughness of my spleen.

I've worn it like a second skin,
So long I've forgotten what's beneath.
The softness that preceded hardness,
The smile that came before clenched teeth.

Yet in the mirror of still waters,
I glimpse another face beyond the rage.
A gentler self waiting patiently,
For fury to complete its stage.

This anger burns deep within,
But even the longest flames must wane.
And in their absence, something grows—
A peace more powerful than pain.

Neither virtue nor a sin,
Just energy off course.

It speaks in tongues of crimson red,
In heartbeats loud and fast,
In words that should remain unsaid,
In shadows that are cast.

I've tried to drown it in the sea,
Of reason and of time,
But still it finds its way to me,
Like bells that always chime.

Perhaps instead of fighting back,
I should listen to its song,
Find wisdom in what I lack,
Learn where these flames belong.

For anger is a teacher stern,
Revealing what we need,
The boundaries we must discern,
The truths we must concede.

This anger burns deep within,
A compass, not a cage,
Guiding where I should begin,
To write my newest page.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'For the first time in my life'

responses.text:

For the first time in my life

FOR THE FIRST TIME IN MY LIFE

For the first time in my life, I touched the edge of time,

For the first time in my life, I tasted raw courage,

For the first time in my life, I am not who I was,

I exist perfectly between effect and cause—

For the first time in my life

I understood the language of falling rain,
each droplet a syllable of some ancient verse
written by clouds that wandered continents
before deciding to weep above my head.

For the first time in my life
I realized my heart was not a muscle
but a migratory bird, restless and wild,
searching for a branch strong enough
to bear the weight of its songs.

For the first time in my life

of everyone's secrets, growing heavier
until it must shed them in silver light
across the sleeping world.

For the first time in my life
I recognized that loneliness isn't absence
but presence—the company of all
who have ever felt the same hollow echo
reverberate through their bones.

For the first time in my life
I am awake. Truly awake.
And the world has never seemed
so terrifying or so beautiful.

FOR THE FIRST TIME IN MY LIFE

For the first time in my life, I saw mountains bow
To the persistence of wildflowers,
Their granite faces softened by purple and gold rebellions
That needed no permission to bloom.

For the first time in my life, I heard
The conversation between wind and leaves,
Their gossip of distant shores and coming storms,

For the first time in my life, I felt

As a butterfly landed on my open palm,

For the first time in my life, I tasted

Letting go of who I thought I should be

For the first time in my life, I understand

And that love is not something to find
But something to finally recognize.

For the first time in my life

I stand at the precipice of myself,
Toes curled over the edge of everything
I thought I knew. Behind me,
The comfortable shadows of yesterday.
Before me, a sky unmarked by paths.

For the first time in my life,
I understand why the moth seeks flame—
Not for destruction but transformation,
The burning away of limits,
The ecstasy of becoming light itself.

For the first time in my life,
I hear the music in silence,
The rhythm of my own blood
Synchronizing with ancient stars
That died to birth this moment.

For the first time in my life,
I recognize my own face
In strangers passing by,
In the eyes of enemies,
In the mirror of river water.

For the first time in my life,
I am neither arriving nor leaving—
Just wonderfully, terribly
Present in the infinite now,
Where all journeys begin and end.

EMERGENCE

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Their flags and their banners they are waving with joy and excitement they shout'

Jubilation

Their flags and their banners they are waving
With joy and excitement they shout,
Colored fabric dancing on the breeze,
Voices rising, breaking out.

A sea of faces turned skyward,
Hands reaching high to touch the sun,
The crowd moves like one breathing creature,

What victory do they celebrate?

Or perhaps it's just begun.

Drums against the dusty ground,
Their hope a tangible presence
In every triumphant sound.

So let them wave their banners high,
Let jubilation fill the air,
For in this moment they are boundless,
United in the joy they share.

Revolution's Dawn

With joy and excitement they shout,

Yesterday's whispers of courage

Will bow down no more.

In this moment of collective power,
A new beginning is made.

Victory's Chorus

The why of their long suffering,
The why of their patient wait,
Now answered in this explosion
Of triumph over fate.

Some weep with unexpected relief,

Some stand in silent reverence,
For what they've finally won.

Remember this day of jubilee,

When voices rose in unison,
And hope became sublime.

Carnival of Souls

Their flags and their banners they are waving
With joy and excitement they shout,
But beneath the noise and revelry,
Lurks meaning more devout.

For what is this celebration
But humanity's ancient need
To gather in collective wonder,

The colors snap and flutter,

We crave these sacred moments

When stranger stands with stranger
In the light of better days.

So wave your flags and banners,
Let your joyful cries ring out,

We discover what life's about.

The Gathering Storm

Their flags and their banners they are waving

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
War's a joke for me and you,
While we sit in cushioned seats,
Watching pixels flash on screens,
Of distant lands we never knew.

We scroll past headlines with a sigh,
Double-tap and then move on,
To cat videos and memes at dawn,
While somewhere children cry.

War's a joke until it's not,
Until the bombs fall at your door,
Until you're counting bodies on the floor,
Until your home is what they sought.

We laugh at leaders' bold decrees,
Their chess game played with human lives,
While mothers wonder who survives,
And soldiers fall to their knees.

War's a joke for me and you,
A bitter punchline we all know,
Yet still we watch the body count grow,
And wonder what else we can do.

War's a joke for me and you,
A game of thrones on distant soil,
Where others bleed and others toil,
While we debate what's false and true.

The generals plan from marble halls,
Moving pins on pristine maps,
While trenches fill with human scraps,
And duty answers desperate calls.

War's a joke we tell ourselves,
To justify the broken bones,
The orphaned cries, the final groans,
The flags that drape on empty shells.

We toast to peace with bloodied hands,
Sign treaties with the ink of tears,
Rebuild the ruins of wasted years,
And plant our crosses in foreign lands.

War's a joke for me and you,
But not for those who know its face,
Who carry scars no time erases,
And hear its laughter their whole lives through.

War's a joke for me and you,
As we watch from safety's shore,
The waves of conflict crash and roar,
On lands we've never traveled to.

We speak of justice, speak of right,
With bellies full and beds secure,
Our righteous words so clean, so pure,
While strangers huddle through the night.

The children learn to duck and run,
Before they learn to write their name,
While we debate who's most to blame,
And share our takes when day is done.

The medals shine on polished chests,
The monuments stand tall and proud,
While silent graves, without a crowd,
Hold those who failed the final tests.

War's a joke for me and you,
A bitter truth we dare not face,
That we're complicit in disgrace,
By letting others die on cue.

War's a joke for me and you,
A headline skimmed at breakfast time,
A distant thunder, not sublime,
But far enough to filter through

As entertainment, dark and strange,
A game of armies, red and blue,
Of territories old and new,
Of powers shifting, rearrange.

We shake our heads and tsk and sigh,
Then argue politics and blame,
As if it's nothing but a game,
While somewhere real people die.

The privilege of peace surrounds
Our bubble of security,
This fragile unreality,
Where war is just a distant sound.

War's a joke for me and you,
Until the day it reaches home,
Until the bombs begin to roam,
And then we'll know what others knew.

War's a joke for me and you,
But not for those who bear the scars,
Who count their losses by the stars,
And measure time by who lived through.

The politicians wage their words,
In chambers safe from flying steel,
Their patriot games seem almost real,
As they send forth their human herds.

The weapons dealers count their gold,
The generals plan another push,
The propaganda masters hush
The voices of the truth untold.

The mothers weep in every land,
Their tears unite across all lines,
Transcending borders, crossing times,
A grief no flag can understand.

War's a joke for me and you,
A tragedy for all mankind,
A sickness of the human mind,
That we keep falling victim to.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
WAR'S LAUGHTER

War's a joke for me and you,
While others bleed and others die.
We sit in comfort, scrolling through
The headlines with a passive sigh.

Metal birds drop fire from skies,
We watch it all on HD screens.
The distance makes it easy to
Forget these are not movie scenes.

War's a joke until it's not,
Until the bombs fall on our street.
Until our loved ones are the ones
Who never made their way back home.

So laugh now if you still can laugh,
At conflicts fought in distant lands.
But know one day the joke might end
With weapons placed in your own hands.

War's a joke for me and you,
A bitter punchline we all share.
The darkest humor of mankind,
A comedy of raw despair.

THE SPECTATORS

'War's a joke for me and you,'
We say from cushioned seats afar,
As others march through mud and blood,
Beneath a smoke-obscured star.

We trade our memes and clever quips,
While nations burn and children weep.
Our laughter echoes, hollow sounds,
Across the graves piled mountain-deep.

What comedy is this we watch?
What punchline waits beyond the screen?
The generals plot their next advance,
While we debate what it might mean.

Perhaps the joke's on us instead,
Who think ourselves above the fray.
The war machine feeds on our clicks,
Our passive gaze from day to day.

'War's a joke for me and you,'
But not for those who know its truth.
Not for the ones who cannot sleep,
Or those who lost their precious youth.

DISTANT THUNDER

'War's a joke for me and you,'
Words spoken from the safety of
Our undisturbed reality,
Where peace remains our common truth.

We trade in quips and clever lines
About the conflicts overseas.
The battles fought by strangers' sons
Become our dinner-table ease.

How strange to laugh at distant pain,
To make a game of others' grief.
To scroll past death with thumbs so quick,
Then wonder why there's no relief.

Perhaps the joke's not ours to tell,
Nor ours to hear with lightened heart.
Perhaps in every bomb that falls,
We bear some uncomfortable part.

So when we say, 'It's just a joke,'
Remember those who cannot smile,
Whose homes are dust, whose dreams are ash,
Whose suffering makes our comfort vile.

THE PRIVILEGED VIEW

'War's a joke for me and you,'
A line that cuts with truth so sharp.
We who have never heard the bombs,
Or felt a homeland torn apart.

We speak of conflicts with detached
Analysis and cool debate.
As if these games on distant boards
Are puzzles for us to relate.

The headlines flash, we shake our heads,
Then turn to sip our morning brew.
The luxury of distance grants
A perspective warped and skewed.

But somewhere children hide in fear,
And mothers search through rubble piles.
Somewhere the joke has lost its mirth,
Revealing horror all the while.

So when we speak of war as sport,
Or politics as mere charade,
Remember that our laughter rings
Across a world that's not been spared.

WILFRED'S GHOST

'War's a joke for me and you,'
Wilfred Owen wrote in pain.
The bitter irony of those
Who'd never feel death's cold rain.

A century has passed since then,
Yet still we sit in comfort's glow,
Disconnected from the truth
Of battlefields we'll never know.

We argue politics with ease,
Draw lines on maps with careless hands.
Our theories float like privileged ghosts
Above the blood-soaked, churning lands.

The old lie persists through time:
Dulce et decorum est—
How sweet and fitting still it seems
To die for causes we contest.

So when we joke of war today,
Remember Owen's ghostly voice.
The bitter laugh from trenches deep
Where men became war's helpless toys.

On conflicts we can't relate.

In history books and on the screen,
We glamorize the war machine,
Heroic tales and medals bright,
Obscuring death's eternal night.

The children play with plastic guns,
Pretending to be chosen ones,
Mimicking what they've been shown,
A violence they have never known.

But somewhere in a shattered land,
A child holds their parent's hand,
And wonders why the skies rain fire,
Why homes become a funeral pyre.

So next time when we jest and quip,
About the bombs and gunship's trip,
Remember war's no laughing game,
For those caught in its deadly flame.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
War's a joke for me and you,
While distant bombs light up the sky.
We sip our coffee, scroll the news,
And with a sigh, we wonder why.

Men in suits declare their games,
Sending others' sons to die.
We share posts and place our blame,
Then scroll on by, then scroll on by.

War's a joke until it's not,
Until the terror reaches home.
Until the bodies that are shot
Have names we've known, have faces shown.

We play spectator to the grief,
Detached from blood on foreign soil.
This comfortable disbelief—
Our privilege, our moral foil.

War's a joke for me and you,
A tragedy for all the rest.
The punchline lands when we see truth:
Our laughter makes us complicit.

WAR'S PUNCHLINE

War's a joke for me and you,
A dark comedy we watch from afar.
Someone else's nightmare come true,
While we debate from the comfort of our car.

We trade memes of leaders' faces,
Reduce suffering to statistics and charts.
While children huddle in bombed-out places,
We argue politics, pretending we're smart.

War's a joke for me and you,
A headline scrolled past with our morning toast.
Another country torn in two,
Another reason to armchair boast.

But listen—can you hear that sound?
Laughter dying in the throats of those
Whose homes and hopes crash to the ground,
Whose lives aren't cushioned like our own.

War's a joke for me and you,
Until the day it isn't anymore.
Until the punchline comes due,
And knocks unwelcome at our door.

SPECTATORS

War's a joke for me and you,
We who have never heard a shell scream overhead,
Nor felt the ground trembling with dread,
Nor carried comrades, newly dead.

We laugh at generals on TV screens,
Their medals bright, their rhetoric grand.
While mothers search through rubble for their sons
In places we can't find on maps, in distant lands.

War's a joke for me and you,
We who debate politics over wine,
Drawing invisible boundary lines,
On tablecloths instead of minefields.

Our battles fought with clever words,
Our wounds healed with a night's good sleep.
While somewhere children learn to duck
Before they learn to read or speak.

War's a joke for me and you,
Until it isn't—until truth breaks through
The comfortable bubble we've constructed,
And we finally see what others always knew.

PRIVILEGED DISTANCE

War's a joke for me and you,
A headline skimmed between commercials,
A topic for intellectual pursuits,
Theoretical, like college rehearsals.

We debate the ethics from our sofas,
Strategize moves we'll never make,
While someone's daughter, someone's son
Bleeds real blood for real stakes.

War's a joke for me and you,
A concept abstract and far away,
While someone counts their final breaths
In a hospital with walls of gray.

We change the channel when it gets too real,
Too graphic for our delicate eyes,
While someone cradles their beloved's head,
And watches as their future dies.

War's a joke for me and you,
But the punchline is our apathy,
Our privilege to remain untouched
By humanity's greatest tragedy.

DISTANT THUNDER

War's a joke for me and you,
A conversation over dinner plates,
While somewhere else the thunder booms
And reshapes someone else's fate.

We read the headlines, shake our heads,
Perhaps we donate, perhaps we pray,
Then turn to sports or celebrity news,
And let our outrage fade away.

War's a joke for me and you,
A political stance, a moral view,
While strangers wrapped in foreign flags
Return in boxes, cold and few.

How strange to live in peaceful times
Yet feast on violence through our screens,
To feel so moved yet so removed
From what destruction really means.

War's a joke for me and you,
Until the day the joke wears thin,
When distance folds and pain arrives
And we discover what has always been—
That laughter dies when truth begins.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:

Laughing at the memes and tweets,

We scroll past horror with our thumbs,

Debate the politics like sport,
Detached from true calamity.

War's a joke until it's not,

Until the bombs fall on your street,

So maybe pause before you laugh,
At distant drums and falling shells,
For war's no joke to those who live,
Inside its many private hells.

War's a joke for me and you,

Who never heard the missiles fly,

We jest and mock from safety's shore,

How strange this distance that we keep,
This veil of privilege drawn tight,
That lets us speak of death and pain,

Perhaps the joke's on us instead,
Who think ourselves so wise and free,
Yet fail to see our complicity,
In this grand comedy-tragedy.

So laugh, my friend, if laugh you must,
But know the punchline costs in blood,
And those who truly know war's face,
Find nothing funny in its flood.

War's a joke for me and you,
A distant game of chess and chance,
While pawns are moved by unseen hands,
And queens and kings lead the dance.

We chuckle at the evening news,
At leaders' boasts and hollow threats,
While somewhere in a field of dust,
A mother buries what she gets.

The joke's not funny anymore,
When children sleep in subway halls,
When hospitals become the front,
And schools collapse from cannon balls.

War's a joke we tell ourselves,
To numb the guilt of looking away,
To justify our silence when,
The powerful have their bloody day.

So let us stop this laughter now,
And face the truth we dare not see,
That war's no joke but mankind's shame,
A stain on our humanity.

War's a joke for me and you,
Or so we're told by those who gain,
From selling arms and drafting youth,
To fields where profit blooms from pain.

We laugh because to weep would mean,
We'd have to act, to rise, to change,
The systems built on broken backs,
The orders we dare not derange.

But somewhere past our borders safe,
The punchline lands with leaden weight,
In cratered homes and poisoned wells,
In refugees who suffocate.

The cosmic joke's on all of us,
Who think ourselves exempt from fate,
Who draw our lines on stolen lands,
And call our violence something great.

So next time when you hear them say,

War's a joke for me and you,
A punchline shared across the years,
By those who've never tasted fear,
Or dried a stranger's bitter tears.

We jest in comfortable rooms,
About the conflicts overseas,
As if destruction's just a game,
That we can pause when we might please.

The irony escapes us not,
How lightly we discuss demise,
While sipping coffee, scrolling screens,

Perhaps in this sardonic line,

That making mockery of war,

So let us laugh, if laugh we must,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'From childhood's hour I have not been'

responses.text:
From childhood's hour I have not been
As others were—I have not seen
As others saw—I could not bring
My passions from a common spring.
From the same source I have not taken
My sorrow; I could not awaken
My heart to joy at the same tone;
And all I loved, I loved alone.

The shadows lengthened as I grew,
My solitude a sacred view
Of worlds unseen by common eyes,
Of whispered truths beneath the skies.
In silence found, in darkness sought,
The universe within my thought—
A lonely path, yet wholly mine,
Where stars in private chambers shine.

From childhood's hour I have not been
One to follow the beaten path.
Instead, I wandered through the glen,
Embracing joy and nature's wrath.

My soul was forged in quiet streams,
In thunderstorms and morning light.
I built my world from vivid dreams
That visited me in the night.

The ordinary never called
With voice enough to turn my head.
I climbed where others would have crawled,
And slept in wisdom's unmade bed.

So here I stand, still set apart,
A traveler from a distant shore.
With compass needle for a heart,
And memories of what came before.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A creature of conformity.
My spirit wild, untamed, serene,
Defied the world's enormity.

I danced in rain when others fled,
I spoke to stars that no one heard.
The universe inside my head
Transformed each thought into a bird.

My mother worried, father frowned,
Teachers labeled me as strange.
But in that difference, I found
A power nothing could arrange.

So pity not this wayward soul
Who walks the edges of your sight.
For while you clutch what makes you whole,
I've learned to breathe in endless night.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A keeper of the common clock.
Time flows differently through my skin,
Like water over weathered rock.

The memories stretch like taffy pulled,
Sweetened by distance, touched by pain.
Some moments crystallized and culled,
Others washed away like rain.

I measure days by feelings felt,
By lessons learned and chances missed.
By how the light at sunset dealt
Its golden cards on fields sun-kissed.

Perhaps we're all adrift in time,
Pretending that we understand
The cosmic rhythm and the rhyme
Of hours slipping through our hand.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A vessel empty, waiting to fill.
Instead, a river, carving within
The landscape of my own free will.

My eyes saw visions, bright and strange,
Where others viewed the mundane world.
My mind, a sky of endless range,
With thoughts like comets, burning, hurled.

The adults said I'd grow and change,
Become like them—contained and neat.
But wildness cannot rearrange
Its nature, nor its truth defeat.

So here I stand, still unconfined,
A child and ancient soul combined.
Neither lost nor fully defined,
A mystery, even to my mind.

From childhood's hour I have not been
