prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

responses.text:
Breath, when sheathed by the web of ebbs,
Suspends in twilight's gossamer hold,
A prisoner caught between heartbeats,
Where time's fingers grow cold.

The lungs—hollow vessels of memory—
Struggle against invisible tides,
As consciousness drifts like autumn leaves
On currents where silence resides.

In this cocoon of momentary death,
Where yesterday meets tomorrow's shore,
The soul dangles from fragile threads,
Neither less alive nor more.

The universe contracts to this:
A chest that fails to rise,
A moment stretched to infinity
Beneath indifferent skies.

Yet in this pause, this sacred void,
When life seems all but spent,
The web of ebbs reveals itself
As but a veil, soon rent.

BREATH ENTANGLED

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
Whispers secrets to the midnight air.
Tracking shadows across lunar landscapes,
It dances between existence and despair.

Caught in the silver threads of time's loom,
Each inhale a rebellion against the void,
Each exhale surrendering what we cannot keep—
The borrowed elements, temporarily employed.

The spider of fate spins without mercy,
Entangling life-force in its patient design.
We struggle like moths in silken cages,
Our wings beating against what we cannot define.

Yet within this mesh of cosmic restraint,
A certain freedom blooms in acceptance.
The web that binds also connects us
To stars and soil in perfect resonance.

So breathe, though sheathed by ebbing tides.
Your mortal rhythm joins the eternal song
Of universes expanding and contracting,
Where even endings cannot last for long.

THE TIDAL SELF

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
Becomes a ghost ship on receding seas.
I watch my chest—this strange geography—
Rise and fall beneath unseen decrees.

The body knows what mind forgets:
We are but water dressed in bone,
Pulled by moons we cannot touch,
Tied to rhythms not our own.

In the space between inhalations,
Where possibility hangs suspended,
I feel the ancient pull of tides
That countless lives have ended.

This breath—my temporary tenant—
Holds the salt of primordial seas,
Carries oxygen like memories
Through the labyrinth of arteries.

How strange to be so governed
By forces we pretend to master,
Our lungs the humble servants
Of ebbs that flow ever faster.

I surrender to this web of being,
This cosmic net that holds us all,
Breathing in the certainty
That even breath must fall.

GOSSAMER CHAINS

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
Is freedom caught in gossamer chains,
A butterfly with dampened wings
Awash in autumn rains.

The diaphragm—that loyal muscle—
Strains against invisible nets,
As lungs collapse like paper lanterns
In a dance of small deaths.

What power holds us to this pattern?
What cosmic hand conducts this flow?
The in-between of breaths contains
All mysteries we cannot know.

I've felt it in the midnight hours
When consciousness begins to drift,
How breath becomes a fragile boat
Set adrift on time's swift shift.

The web of ebbs—both trap and cradle—
Holds us in its gentle grasp,
Reminding with each measured breath
That nothing here is meant to last.

Yet in this temporary binding,
This sheathing of our mortal air,
Lies beauty in surrendering
To forces beyond compare.

INTERSTITIAL

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
Dwells in spaces between definition,
Neither coming nor going, but hovering—
A quantum state of indecision.

The chest, a cathedral of bone and blood,
Holds its sermon in momentary pause,
As if contemplating its own existence
Beyond the reach of natural laws.

I have known this suspension,
This hanging between worlds,
When anxiety wraps its fingers tight
And the flag of surrender unfurls.

The web of ebbs is no mere metaphor
But the very fabric of our being,
The invisible matrix that connects
What is with what is fleeing.

We are creatures of threshold spaces,
Always crossing, never arrived,
Our breath the only constant
In a universe deprived

Of certainty or solid ground.
So I embrace this sheathed moment,
This breath caught in time's web,
And make it my home, my atonement.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

responses.text:
Breath When Sheathed by the Web of Ebbs

In the hollow spaces between heartbeats,

Each inhale a rebellion against surrender,
Each exhale a submission to the pattern.

We are caught, are we not?
In this delicate lattice of coming and going,
Of filling and emptying our fragile vessels.

The spider of moments spins silently,

In its intricate design of hours.

And I, ensnared in this web of ebbs,
Find strange comfort in constraint,
For even as my breath is sheathed,
It remains—persistent, patient, pure—
A quiet defiance against the inevitable flow.

The Tidal Self

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
Grows shallow in the chest of night,
A prisoner to the moon's slow pull,
A captive of retreating light.

The gossamer strands that bind us here
Are spun from salt and ancient tears,

Into the depths of nameless fears.

What creatures lurk in exposed sand?

The web of ebbs reveals to us
The hidden chambers of the heart.

So let me dwell in this retreat,
This momentary space between—
For in the sheathing of my breath,
I glimpse what others haven't seen:

That we are ocean, we are tide,
Forever flowing, out and in.
The web that seems to hold us back
Is where our true lives begin.

Gossamer Cage

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
Dances like dust motes caught in light,
Trapped between the was and will be,
Suspended in the liminal night.

I feel my lungs constrict and strain
Against invisible silken cords,
Woven by time's relentless spinners,
Tightening with unspoken words.

The air grows thin within this mesh,
This lattice of retreating tides,
Where exhalation meets resistance,
And inhalation barely bides.

What strange cocoon is this becoming?
What metamorphosis awaits?
The web of ebbs both shields and strangles,
Both liberates and suffocates.

Perhaps in this constricted state,
Where breath no longer flows as stream
But pulses slow like distant stars,
We touch the edges of a dream.

For in the spaces between breaths,
When sheathed in withdrawal's gentle grasp,
The soul finds room to stretch beyond
The body's temporary clasp.

Tidal Whispers

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
Is a whisper caught between worlds—
Neither here in the realm of substance
Nor there in the void of possibility.

I stand at the shoreline of myself,
Watching as the waters recede,
Revealing strange and barnacled truths
That the high tide of living conceals.

This breath, now cradled in retreat,

The lungs, like empty chambers,
Await the inevitable return.
For every ebb must yield to flow,
Every absence promise presence.

So I surrender to this sheathing,

Knowing that in the web of ebbs
Lies the pattern of all existence.

The Receding

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
Curls inward like a frightened fern,
Retreating from the edge of being
To where the embers barely burn.

I've felt this drawing back before—

That tethers soul to mortal coil,
The tension that makes silence sing.

The spider of the universe
Spins threads of silver-shadowed doubt
Across the chambers of my chest
Where air moves gently in and out.

What wisdom in this slow withdraw,

The ocean knows to gather strength
Before it reaches far and wide.

Perhaps our breath when bound and held
In networks of receding force
Is teaching us the power found
In pausing on life's winding course.

So let me rest within this web,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I Always See To It

I always see to it that morning dew
Remains undisturbed on spider's silk,
That children's laughter echoes through
The hollow spaces where doubts once built.

I always see to it that promises made
Are kept like treasures, polished and true,
That kindness flows in words unsaid
In gentle actions, old and new.

I always see to it that time won't steal
The memories we've carefully grown,
That love remains the way we feel
When darkness comes and we're alone.

I always see to it, this sacred task,
This quiet duty that shapes my days.
In tending to the things that last,
I find my purpose, chart my ways.

Guardian's Pledge

I always see to it that embers don't die,
Cradling flames against winter's harsh breath.
Whispering life into moments that fly,
Standing guard between living and death.

I always see to it—a promise unspoken,
Shouldering burdens too heavy to name.
Mending the pieces of all that's been broken,
Never once thinking to shift any blame.

I always see to it the path remains clear,
Sweeping away both the thorns and the stones.
Staying awake through the night when you fear,
Ensuring you never must face it alone.

I always see to it, though no one may know
The cost of this vigil I silently keep.
Watching and waiting as seasons still flow,
A sentinel's duty too sacred for sleep.

Caretaker

I always see to it the stars have a home
In the vast empty canvas of night,
That the moon finds its path as it starts to roam
And the sun knows when to shine bright.

I always see to it the birds have a song
When morning breaks through the trees,
That the wind knows exactly where it belongs
As it dances through autumn leaves.

I always see to it your coffee is warm,
Your blankets are folded with care,
That someone is waiting when day grows worn
With patience beyond compare.

I always see to it that love doesn't fade
In the rush of our hurried years.
I am the keeper of promises made,
The guardian of hopes and fears.

Unsung Duties

I always see to it—this mantra, my creed,
Unspoken devotion that guides every step.
No fanfare or glory, no witness or deed
Recorded in history's kept.

I always see to it the letters are sent,
The birthdays remembered, the tears wiped away.
The thousand small kindnesses, heaven-sent,
That stitch together each ordinary day.

I always see to it the garden still blooms
When others have long since abandoned their posts.
I tend to the living, I honor the tombs,
I welcome both strangers and ghosts.

I always see to it—four words that contain
A lifetime of service, of showing up true.
Through sunshine and storm clouds, through joy and through pain,
This work of the heart, ever new.

The Unseen Hand

I always see to it, though no one may notice
The invisible labors that fill up my days.
Like breath to the body, like rain to the lotus,
I move through the world in unrecognized ways.

I always see to it the clock keeps its rhythm,
The shelves remain dusted, the floors remain clean.
I am the solution to problems unwritten,
The force that maintains what remains unseen.

I always see to it your world doesn't falter,
That systems don't break and that chaos won't reign.
My vigilance serves as an unspoken altar
To order and peace I strive to maintain.

I always see to it—perhaps my salvation,
Perhaps my undoing, this need to ensure
That everything functions without hesitation.
My purpose is simple: endure and endure.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I Always See To It

I always see to it. Four words that bind
My soul to service, promise to fulfill.
Four words that echo through my heart and mind,

Custodian of Small Things

I always see to it that the spider
finds safe passage from my bathroom sink.
Cupped palms become a temporary shelter,
a bridge between worlds. I've come to think

that mercy lies in these minor rescues—
the fallen nestling returned to its branch,
the misplaced letter finally mailed,
the forgotten promise suddenly kept.

I always see to it that candles
burn in windows during winter storms,
their trembling light a constellation
for anyone lost in the dark.

My mother taught me this attention,
her hands always moving toward completion—
dishes washed, beds made, tears dried,
each task honored with quiet devotion.

I always see to it that nothing
remains unfinished in my wake.
The world breaks enough without my help.
I choose instead to be the one who stays,
who witnesses, who remembers,
who carries through what others abandon.
In this way, I have become a keeper
of continuance, a guardian of follow-through.

Vigilance

I always see to it
that the door is locked at night,
that the children's breath moves
in peaceful rhythm while they sleep.

I always see to it
that the words I speak contain
more kindness than necessary,
for I've learned how syllables can bruise.

I always see to it
that promises made are kept,
even when inconvenient,
especially when difficult.

I always see to it
that flowers receive water,
that birds find seed in winter,
that strangers encounter my smile.

I always see to it
that memories are preserved
in photographs and stories,
guarded against time's slow erasure.

I always see to it
that love isn't merely spoken
but demonstrated in the
thousand daily gestures of care.

I always see to it—
this mantra of responsibility,
this quiet oath of attention,
this burden I've chosen to carry.

For what else is living
but the endless vigilance
of seeing to what matters,
making certain nothing precious slips away?

The Caretaker's Creed

I always see to it that daybreak
finds me ready, sleeves rolled high,
hands prepared for whatever breaks,
whatever falls, whatever dies.

I always see to it—this mantra
passed through generations like
a tarnished locket, words worn smooth
as river stones, their meaning clear:

Nothing should be left undone.
No promise broken. No debt unpaid.
No letter unanswered. No grave unvisited.
No anniversary forgotten.

I always see to it that flowers
bloom where I have planted them,
that friendships flourish under
my attentive cultivation.

Some call it duty. Others, love.
Perhaps they're one and same—
this compulsion to complete,
to finish what's begun.

I always see to it.
Four words that form the spine
of who I am—the architecture
of my most essential self.

Even as the body fails,
as memory dims, as strength departs,
I will see to it until the end—
this final act of faithful stewardship.

Inheritance

I always see to it,
my grandmother would say,
hands moving steadily through
the rituals of preservation—
tomatoes sealed in jars like jewels,
stitches placed with mathematical precision,
letters answered the day they arrived.

I always see to it,
she'd murmur, checking locks
before bed, counting heads
at family gatherings, remembering
birthdays without calendars.

I always see to it—
words passed to my mother
who passed them to me,
a lineage of women who
understand that attention
is its own form of prayer.

Now I find myself speaking
the same incantation
as I water plants, pay bills,
stitch torn seams, tend wounds,
remember anniversaries.

I always see to it
that nothing falls through cracks,
that no one walks away unfed,
that what can be mended is mended,
that what can be saved is saved.

I've become the keeper
of this humble magic—
the alchemy of seeing things through,
of carrying responsibility
like water in cupped hands,
careful not to spill a drop.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I Always See To It

I always see to it that morning light
finds purchase on my weathered windowsill.
I straighten picture frames when they tilt right,
and water dying plants against their will.

I always see to it that promises
don't wither in the shadow of my doubt.
I gather fallen petals, witnesses
to beauty that refuses to burn out.

I always see to it that kindness flows
like rivers seeking oceans in the night.
I mend the broken fences, heaven knows
the world needs fewer walls and more delight.

I always see to it, this sacred task—
to tend the garden others might forsake.
To lift the veil, remove the hollow mask,
and cherish every moment, wide awake.

Keeper of Small Things

i always see to it
that the birds have seeds in winter
that the kettle doesn't whistle too long
that your side of the bed stays warm

i always see to it
that the letters get mailed
that the clocks stay wound
that your name remains
unscarred on my lips

i always see to it
that the stars are counted
that promises don't slip
through cracks in conversation
that memories are folded neatly

i always see to it
even when my hands tremble
even when my vision blurs
even when the weight of seeing
becomes the heaviest thing I carry

i always see to it
because someone must tend
to these fragile, ordinary miracles
because someone must witness
the relentless beauty of continuation

VIGILANCE

i always see to it
that shadows don't linger too long
in corners where light has forgotten its purpose

i always see to it
that silence doesn't grow teeth
and devour conversations we meant to have

i sweep away cobwebs of regret
from the attic of memory
polish tarnished moments until they gleam
with something resembling truth

i always see to it
that hope isn't just a word
but a lantern carried through storms

i guard against the erosion of wonder
the slow theft of possibility
the quiet surrender to less-than

i always see to it
even when my eyes grow heavy
even when vigilance costs more than I can afford
even when nobody notices the keeping

because seeing to it
is how I make peace with a world
that refuses to see itself clearly

The Caretaker's Creed

i always see to it
that the moon has a path across the lake
even when clouds conspire against light

i always see to it
that your name is spoken with reverence
like a prayer that hasn't yet learned
it has already been answered

i tend to the small fires of hope
when winter settles in your bones
and collect rainwater for droughts
you haven't yet encountered

i always see to it
that doors remain unlocked
for the versions of ourselves
still finding their way home

i catalog constellations
in the freckles across your shoulders
map territories of tenderness
where we might someday build

i always see to it
not because duty demands
but because love, at its core,
is attention that refuses to waver

i always see to it
because someone must witness
the quiet miracle of continuation

CUSTODIAN

i always see to it—
this burden of attention,
this blessing of vigilance.

When others turn away,
I remain, eyes fixed
on what must not be forgotten.

I count heartbeats in empty rooms,
sweep footprints from abandoned shores,
keep time when clocks surrender.

i always see to it
that nothing precious disappears
without proper ceremony.

I document the changing light,
archive the shifting shadows,
preserve what others deem disposable.

This is not martyrdom
but a peculiar form of greed—
wanting to witness everything.

i always see to it
that history has a faithful scribe,
that beauty finds its witness,
that pain meets acknowledgment,
that joy encounters recognition.

Someone must stand guard
at the threshold between being and forgetting.
Someone must testify.

i always see to it,
even when seeing breaks me open,
even when it costs everything.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I Always See To It

I always see to it that morning light
finds its way through parted curtains,
that coffee brews while birds announce
the day's uncertain promises.

I always see to it that letters
are answered, that voices on the phone
receive my fullest attention, that
the plants are watered, doors are locked.

I always see to it that others
are comfortable before myself,
that kindness precedes judgment,
that listening outlasts speaking.

Yet who sees to the keeper of things?
Who tends the tender of wounds?
Who witnesses the witness
as she moves through rooms at dusk,

turning on lamps against the growing dark,
seeing to it, always seeing to it.

CARETAKER

I always see to it
that the dead flowers are removed from vases,
that the milk hasn't soured,
that your favorite shirt is pressed.

I always see to it
that bills are paid before due dates,
that birthdays aren't forgotten,
that there's gas in both our cars.

I always see to it
that your mother gets her calls,
that the children have their lunches,
that appointments aren't missed.

I always see to it
that everyone is cared for,
that all tasks reach completion,
that no detail slips away.

I always see to it
that I fade into background,
that my needs remain unspoken,
that my wounds heal on their own.

I always see to it
that nobody sees me seeing to it.

VIGILANCE

I always see to it that shadows
don't linger where they shouldn't,
that monsters under beds are banished,
that nightmares cannot take root.

I always see to it that justice,
however small, finds its way home—
the spider carried outside,
the argument fairly resolved.

I always see to it, this burden
of watchfulness, this curse of care,
this blessing of attention that
weighs heavy as cathedral bells.

Sometimes I wish I could unsee,
unknow, release the grip of duty.
But even then, I'd see to that too—
ensure my blindness was complete.

For what am I if not the one
who always, always sees to it?
This is my purpose, my devotion:
to witness, to act, to complete.

INHERITANCE

I always see to it, like my mother before me,
who learned from her mother's careful hands—
this lineage of women who notice
when the salt is low, when tears need drying.

I always see to it, this invisible labor
passed down like tarnished silver,
polished through generations until
it gleams with expected perfection.

I always see to it that history
doesn't repeat its harshest lessons,
that children know they're cherished,
that love outweighs obligation.

I always see to it, even when
my bones ache with tiredness,
even when my name goes unspoken
for days among those I serve.

I always see to it, and sometimes wonder
if my daughter watches, learning
this ancient choreography of care—
whether to continue it or break free.

PROMISES

I always see to it
that promises don't dissolve
like sugar in rain, that words
spoken become actions taken.

I always see to it
that the path is cleared
of obstacles others might trip on,
that lanterns are lit against darkness.

I always see to it
that truth finds its voice
even when lies would be easier,
that courage stands when fear tempts retreat.

I always see to it
that love isn't just a word
but a daily practice, a revolution,
a quiet persistence against indifference.

I always see to it
that I remain unfinished,
a work in constant progress,
a student of my own failings.

I always see to it—
this is my covenant with living,
my contract with the universe:
to see, to act, to complete.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold
The world shrinks to tissue boxes and steam,
My throat a desert, my head a stone.
I remember when health was invisible,
Taken for granted like morning light.

Now fever paints the hours yellow,
Time stretches like taffy between doses,
And I become a collection of symptoms,
Rather than a person whole.

How strange that such a small thing—
Invisible invaders multiplying—
Can reduce me to this shivering child,
Craving soup and gentle words.

Now when I have a cold
I understand my fragile place,
The thin membrane between wellness and want,
And in this temporary weakness
Find a curious strength:
The knowledge that I will rise again,
Breathing clear, moving unhindered,
Grateful for the simple gift
Of air passing easily
Through an untroubled nose.

Now when I have a cold
The universe contracts to a single tissue,
A drop of medicine, the warmth of tea.
Each breath becomes negotiation,
A careful treaty between lungs and air.

I cocoon in blankets, a chrysalis
Of self-pity and vapor rub,
Time measured in sneezes and coughs,
The percussion of illness marking hours.

My body, once reliable servant,
Now mutinous and strange,
Hosts unwelcome microscopic guests
That throw loud parties in my sinuses.

Friends become distant planets,
Orbiting beyond my quarantine,
Their healthy existence a half-remembered dream
As I drift through mucus-clouded days.

Yet in this foggy isolation,
I find unexpected clarity:
How precious the ordinary miracle
Of breathing without thought,
Of tasting food, of sleeping deep.
Now when I have a cold,
I remember what it means to be alive.

Now when I have a cold,
I become a dragon of sorts—
Breathing fire through a raw throat,
Hoarding tissues like golden coins,
My voice transformed to graveled roar.

The world outside continues spinning
While I orbit my own sun of discomfort,
A planet knocked from its usual path,
Trailing tissues like comet dust.

My head, a glass bowl filled with cotton,
My eyes, two watery moons,
My nose, a perpetual fountain—
I am remade by microscopic architects
Into something less than human,
More than miserable.

Time slows to honey-drip pace
As I count ceiling cracks and sips of tea,
Measuring existence in spoonfuls of medicine
And the brief respites between sneezes.

Now when I have a cold,
I understand the poetry of wellness,
The sonnet of clear breathing,
The haiku of taste buds functioning,
The epic verse of energy returned—
And promise to remember this lesson
When health inevitably restores me
To my forgetful, grateful self.

Now when I have a cold
I become a walking pharmacy,
Pockets bulging with lozenges,
Sleeves doubling as tissues when desperation strikes.
I am the alchemist, transforming
Hot water, lemon, honey
Into gold-standard relief.

Now when I have a cold
Time acquires new dimensions.
Nights stretch into infinity,
Breath becomes a puzzle to solve,
And dreams fever-dance across
The ceiling of my congested mind.

The world divides neatly in two:
Those who are sick, those who are not.
I watch the healthy with alien eyes,
Their easy movements, their casual breath,
Remembering when I too moved
Through the world unburdened.

Now when I have a cold
I understand my grandmother's remedies,
The wisdom in her steaming pots,
The love embedded in her insistence
On rest, on warmth, on patience.

This temporary exile from wellness
Teaches what health cannot—
The precious ordinary miracle
Of breathing clear, of tasting sweet,
Of waking rested from dreamless sleep.

Now when I have a cold
I become a cartography of discomfort,
Mapping the shifting territories
Of congestion and fever.
My sinuses—unexplored caves
Filling with strange waters.
My chest—a contested landscape
Where coughs stake their claim.

The boundaries of my world contract
To the distance between bed and bathroom,
Kitchen and couch. The epic journey
For another box of tissues.

Time becomes elastic, stretching
Through sleepless nights,
Compressing during brief moments
When medication grants reprieve.

I develop new relationships with neglected things:
The ceiling's subtle patterns,
The radiator's rhythmic clicking,
The precise temperature at which
Tea soothes a raw throat.

Now when I have a cold
I understand my body's betrayal
Is actually its fierce devotion—
An army of cells at war for me,
And I learn again the patient art
Of healing, of waiting,
Of believing in the inevitable return
To the person I was before,
But somehow changed—more grateful
For the simple gift of breathing clear.

Through the eloquent insistence of its breaking.

Now when I have a cold
The universe contracts to this:
A bed, a book, a steaming mug,
The slow drip of minutes from the clock.

My senses, normally faithful servants,
Become unreliable narrators—
Taste buds lie dormant, scents elude me,
Sound filters through cotton-stuffed ears.

I watch through windows as others
Navigate their unburdened days,
Moving with a grace I temporarily forget,
Breathing without conscious effort.

In this congested meditation,
I find unexpected gratitude
For the ordinary miracle
Of clear passages and painless swallows.

Now when I have a cold,
I am reminded that health is not permanent,
But a generous visitor
Whose absence teaches appreciation.

Now when I have a cold,
I become an island nation,
Surrounded by seas of blankets,
My borders closed to all but essential visitors.

The economy of my body slows,
Energy reserves depleted,
Production down in all sectors,
A recession of wellness and vigor.

Language simplifies to basic needs:
'Water,' 'Sleep,' 'Medicine,'
The complex vocabulary of daily life
Reduced to elemental survival.

Night and day blur together
In a fever-dream continuum,
Where time is measured only
By the rhythm of labored breath.

Now when I have a cold,
I understand my body's revolution,
The microscopic uprising that reminds me
Of the delicate democracy within my cells.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold
The world shrinks to tissue boxes and steam,
My breath a dragon's wheeze
Against the window pane.

Once-sharp senses dulled,
I taste nothing but the bitter
Medicine on my tongue,
Smell nothing but the mentholated
Vapors of temporary relief.

My body becomes a stranger,
A vessel of aches that creak
Like an old wooden ship in storm.

Yet in this foggy state,
I find a curious clarity—
How fragile we are,
How we take for granted
The simple miracle of breathing freely.

Now when I have a cold,
I remember what it means
To be merely human,
And how quickly we forget
Until the smallest virus
Reminds us of our limits.

Now when I have a cold
The universe collapses into
A symphony of sniffles and sighs.
I am the conductor of phlegm,
A maestro of misery.

My nose, a rebellious faucet
That knows no master but chaos.
My throat, sandpaper against silk.

The tea kettle whistles
A mocking tune as I shuffle
From couch to bed to bathroom,
A pilgrimage of discomfort.

Blankets become my kingdom,
Tissues my loyal subjects,
Scattered across the landscape
Of my temporary isolation.

Time stretches like honey,
Thick and slow and golden
In the afternoon light that peeks
Through curtains I'm too weary to open.

Now when I have a cold,
I am reminded that the body
Is both fortress and traitor,
And that even the smallest invaders
Can bring the mightiest to their knees.

Now when I have a cold,
I become a planet unto myself—
A sphere of aches orbiting
Around the sun of fever.

My sinuses, once clear passages,
Transform to caverns filled
With the stalagmites of congestion.

I count the hours in coughs,
Mark days by the diminishing
Height of tissue mountains.

Sleep comes in fragments,
Dreams vivid with delirium,
As if the virus carries messages
From some forgotten realm.

Friends appear as distant stars,
Their voices echo through
The cotton-stuffed corridors
Of my clouded consciousness.

Now when I have a cold,
I understand the poetry of pause—
How the body demands attention,
How it whispers beneath the noise
Of our ambitions: remember
You are first and finally flesh,
A beautiful, breakable thing.

Now when I have a cold
The minutes drip like medicine,
Slow and measured against
The spoon of my patience.

I wrap myself in blankets,
A caterpillar dreaming
Of metamorphosis back
To wellness, to wings.

The kettle sings its familiar song,
A lullaby of steam and promise
As lemon and honey dance
In the porcelain ballroom.

Outside, the world continues
Its relentless spin, indifferent
To my small suffering,
My temporary removal from its stage.

Books pile beside me,
Unread companions in quarantine,
Their stories waiting for
A clearer mind to receive them.

Now when I have a cold,
I learn again the art of surrender,

But in the gentle acceptance

Now when I have a cold,

The person I was
Before this viral invasion.

My voice, a stranger's rasp,

Of my chest, a ghost

The clock on the wall
Mocks with its steady tick,
Each second a reminder
Of health's precious currency,

I build monuments of
Used tissues, a testament
To this microscopic battle.
Victory measured in degrees,

Now when I have a cold,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen away the blossoms of my spring;
Leaving behind a landscape bare and smooth,
Where once wild dreams took flight on hopeful wing.

The mirror shows what I refuse to see—
Silver threads among the darkened crown,
Laughing lines where smooth skin used to be,
Years collected while I wasn't looking down.

Yet in this theft, a treasure has been left:
Wisdom earned through seasons come and gone,
Memories like jewels, of youth bereft,
But richer now as time keeps marching on.

So though the thief has taken what was mine,
He cannot steal the soul that still will shine.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept on silent paws through waning days,
Unnoticed until truth confronts with truth:
The hourglass empties in peculiar ways.

Yesterday I danced with boundless might,
Today my bones protest at simple tasks.
Memories flicker like a candle's light—
Who was I beneath discarded masks?

The thief takes payment in gray hairs and sighs,
In lessons learned through heartbreak's bitter pill,
In laughter lines that frame these aging eyes,
In dreams surrendered to life's compromise.

Yet something precious grows where youth once stood:
A quiet strength, hard-earned and understood.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Whispered through my window while I slept,
Siphoning moments with relentless ruth,
Harvesting days I thought I would have kept.

The calendar's pages flutter and fall,
Seasons shift beneath unconscious feet.
Summer's warmth yields to autumn's gentle call,
As time performs its vanishing complete.

I search for fingerprints the thief might leave—
A wrinkle here, a memory there, half-faded.
The evidence compounds while I perceive
The masterful deception time has traded.

For what it steals, it leaves a different wealth:
The deepened understanding of myself.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Plucked petals from my once-abundant bloom.
I never felt the pillage, that's the truth—
So gradual the pathway to my doom.

The mirror shows a stranger's face today,
With weathered map of choices etched in skin.
The carefree child has somehow slipped away,
Replaced by one who knows what might have been.

I chase the phantom of my younger self
Through corridors of memory's labyrinth,
Like dusty volumes stacked upon a shelf—
The chapters closed, the endings pre-ordained.

Yet in this theft, I find a strange release:
The burden of potential now at peace.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Danced away with springtime's tender green,
Leaving autumn's gold—a different truth,
Rich with depth unseen in what had been.

The child I was would hardly know this face,
Marked by journeys through both joy and pain.
Each line a story, each scar a place
Where life carved wisdom through its sweet refrain.

Thief, you've taken what I cannot name—
That boundless sense that days would never end,
That innocent belief all stays the same.
Yet what you've left, I've come to comprehend:

A quieter beauty in the fading light,
A deeper peace as day transforms to night.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:

Chronos Unbound

I woke today to find my hands now bear

The Clock's Conspiracy

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Pilfered the treasure I had thought secure—
The boundless energy, the simple truth
That tomorrow would always bring more.

The clock face grins with knowing, ticking hands,
Conspirator in this grand larceny;
Ticking away my hours like shifting sands,
Leaving behind the shell of what would be.

I search for footprints of my younger self,
That carefree spirit dancing in the rain;
Now relegated to memory's shelf,
A ghost that will not visit me again.

Yet in this theft, perhaps a gift is found:
Appreciation for each moment's sound.

The Invisible Pickpocket

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Plucked petals from my once-abundant bloom.

No warning bell, no footsteps in the night,

The morning mirror captures in its sight
The evidence of Time's mysterious ways.

Where once I leapt, now measured steps I take;

Now caution guides the choices that I make—
The price of wisdom growing ever dear.

Yet though this thief has robbed me bit by bit,

Hourglass Memories

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Whispered away my springtime without sound.
Like morning mist that vanishes, in truth,

I never felt the moment's gentle shift

No warning given of the coming drift,
No chance to clutch what's destined now to fall.

The photographs show faces I once wore,
With brighter eyes and skin unmarked by years;
A gallery of selves that are no more,
Preserved in paper memories and tears.

But Time, though thieving youth with crafty hand,

Hourglass Rebellion

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:
Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through the mist of morning dew.
Steel yourself, for duty's calling,
As the sun breaks through anew.

Fold away your dreams of home,
Tuck them safely in your heart.
Shoulders back and spine now straighten,
Time for courage to impart.

Did you hear the bugle singing?
Did you feel the earth's soft sigh?
As another dawn is breaking,
Painting gold across the sky.

Soldier, wake - your brothers need you,
Stand beside them, firm and true.
For the battlefield awaits you,
And the oaths you swore to do.

May your steps be ever steady,
May your aim be ever true.
May you find your way back homeward,
When your fighting days are through.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Golden fingers stretch and pry
At the darkness slowly creeping
Back into the western sky.

Do you hear the silence breaking?
As the birds begin to sing,
Nature's chorus gently shaking
Memories that nightmares bring.

Rise now from your fitful slumber,
Shake the ghosts that haunt your dreams.
Yesterday's fears now outnumber
Today's hopes, or so it seems.

But the morning brings renewal,
Promise wrapped in amber light.
Each dawn offers something crucial:
Chance to set the world aright.

Soldier, breathe - the day is waiting,
Full of moments yet untold.
Life beyond the war is stating:
Wake, for peace you may behold.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
From behind the mountain's crest.
While the world was softly sleeping,
You stood guard so all could rest.

Mist dissolves on distant valleys,
Dew adorns the spider's lace.
Time to rise from shadowed alleys,
Greet the morning's gentle grace.

Stars retreat from heaven's keeping,
Yielding to the sun's command.
Thoughts of home come softly creeping,
Memories of distant land.

Polish boots and check your rifle,
Straighten corners of your bed.
Mundane tasks may seem a trifle,
But they clear the clouded head.

Soldier, wake - new light is streaming,
Breathing life to dormant earth.
In this moment, find new meaning,
In this dawn, discover worth.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through the canvas of your tent.
Nightmares fade as light comes creeping,
Healing what the darkness rent.

Fields of battle lie before you,
Not of guns but daily bread.
Different wars now hover o'er you,
Fighting doubts and fears instead.

Take your helmet off, dear warrior,
Lay your weapons gently down.
You've survived as time's courier,
Bringing peace to hearth and town.

Scars may mark your skin and spirit,
Tales of courage etched in pain.
But the morning doesn't fear it,
Washing clean what does remain.

Soldier, breathe - the world is turning,
You've survived another night.
Dawn's soft fingers, gently burning,
Guide your soul back toward the light.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Like a child behind a door.
Shadows of the night retreating,
As the light floods o'er the floor.

Dust motes dance in golden sunbeams,
Rifle gleams with oiled sheen.
Remnants of your fading night-dreams,
Slip away from what has been.

Comrades stir in bunks around you,
Mumbling prayers or curses low.
Each with private thoughts that found you,
In the dark some hours ago.

Lace your boots with practiced fingers,
Straighten sheets with military pride.
That old ache in your chest lingers,
For the home you left aside.

Soldier, rise - your duty's calling,
Breakfast steam and coffee's scent.
Stand tall though the night was galling,
This new day is heaven-sent.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes
Where broken dreams collect like toll,
I've driven past midnight's shadow,
With nothing but echoes to console.

Tarmac stretches, endless black,
Marked by tears that never dried.
Yellow lines like stitches
On wounds that time has never tied.

Signposts point to destinations
That shimmer like mirages ahead,
Promising relief from this journey
Where hope hangs by a thread.

At the highways of woes
Strangers pass with downcast eyes,
All of us following separate roads
Under the same fractured skies.

Yet even here, where sorrow dwells,
Wildflowers break through concrete cracks,
Whispering that pain is but a passage,
A road that eventually tracks back.

At the highways of woes
I found myself wandering alone,
Feet blistered from the journey,
Heart heavy as stone.

Traffic lights blink red to yellow to green,
But I remain still at the crossing,
Watching others rush toward destinations
While I'm perpetually lost in.

The median strip blooms with weeds,
Tenacious life amid exhaust and noise,
Teaching me that even desolation
Can harbor unexpected joys.

Cars honk impatient symphonies,
As I gather courage to proceed,
Knowing that these roads of sorrow
Are where the strongest spirits breed.

At the highways of woes,
I finally understand—
Every path of suffering
Leads to promised land.

At the highways of woes
We are merely passing through,
Travelers with heavy luggage
Filled with memories, old and new.

The asphalt burns beneath our feet,
Melting like our yesterdays,
Roadside motels offer temporary shelter
From the storm that never stays.

Guardrails bent from countless crashes
Of souls who drove too fast or blind,
While billboards advertise salvation
Just a few more miles behind.

I've seen faces in rearview mirrors
Disappearing at the curve,
Ghosts of choices never taken,
Regrets I didn't deserve.

At the highways of woes
The fuel gauge reading low,
Yet somehow we keep moving,
To destinations we don't know.

At the highways of woes
The moon hangs like a broken plate,
Illuminating paths diverged
By the cruel hands of fate.

Trucks laden with burdens
Thunder past in midnight rain,
Splashing memories against my windshield
That wipers clear in vain.

Gas stations glow like lighthouses,
Beacons for the lost and tired,
Offering momentary respite
Before the journey's fire.

I've counted mile markers
Like a prisoner counts days,
Wondering when this endless road
Will break from sorrow's maze.

At the highways of woes
We are all reluctant pilgrims,
Seeking exits toward redemption,
Finding strength in silent hymns.

At the highways of woes
I planted seeds of resilience,
Between cracked concrete and emptiness,
A garden of defiance.

The eighteen-wheelers of despair
Roared past my fragile plot,
Exhaust fumes of doubt and fear
Threatening all I've got.

I watered stems with teardrops,
Fertilized with broken dreams,
Yet somehow green shoots emerged
More powerful than they seem.

Travelers stop sometimes now
To marvel at the sight:
How beauty blooms so fiercely
In darkness toward the light.

At the highways of woes
I've built my humble home,
Transforming paths of suffering
Into sacred fertile loam.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes
Where broken dreams scatter like leaves,
I've traveled with soles worn thin,
Collecting heartaches that nobody sees.

Each mile marker counts regrets,
Toll booths demanding payment in tears,
The asphalt stretches endlessly ahead
Paved with the concrete of my fears.

Fellow travelers pass in blurred faces,

Of this journey we cannot disclaim.

The yellow lines fade into darkness

Yet somewhere beyond the horizon

At the highways of woes

And suffering cannot remain.

AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

At the highways of woes, I stand contemplating
The intersections of sorrow and pain,
Where traffic lights flicker between hope and despair,
And roadkill dreams lie rotting in rain.

Exhaust fumes of memories cloud my vision,
As eighteen-wheelers of grief thunder past,
Carrying cargo too heavy for bridges
Built from the timber of futures now cast.

Billboards advertise happiness for purchase,
Exit ramps promise escape from this place,
But detours and construction work block the way forward,
And GPS signals of purpose lose trace.

Yet I've packed lunches of courage in paper bags,

For even along these highways of woes,
Wildflowers of beauty somehow survive.

So I merge back into traffic, hands steady,
Navigating potholes of doubt with new skill,
For beyond these highways of infinite woes,
Waits a destination worth climbing the hill.

At the highways of woes
Where shadows stretch like endless roads
I found myself wandering, barefoot and cold
Carrying stories that never grew old.

The pavement cracked beneath my step
Each fissure a memory I've wept
Of loves abandoned by roadsides past
And futures sacrificed, never to last.

Signposts pointing to nowhere and everywhere
Directions meaningless when in despair
Yet still I trudge through blinding rain
Seeking shelter from relentless pain.

Cars rush by in blurred streaks of light
Drivers oblivious to my plight
Their destinations certain, paths clear
While I remain, paralyzed by fear.

But wait—what's this? A fellow ghost
Walking these highways that hurt the most
We share a glance, a moment true
Suddenly the woes feel less like rue.

Perhaps these highways weren't built for grief alone
But for finding others who also roam
At the highways of woes, I now understand
We're never truly lost when we walk hand in hand.

AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

At the highways of woes
I've driven through midnight storms,
Windshield wipers barely keeping pace
With the downpour of my own making.

The road signs blur into watercolors,
Destinations I once sought with fervor
Now mere ghosts haunting rearview mirrors,
Distances measured in heartbeats and sighs.

I've picked up hitchhikers along the way—
Regret with his heavy suitcase,
Doubt wearing her tattered coat,
Shame with eyes that never meet mine.

The radio plays static symphonies,
Occasionally broken by voices
That sound like everyone I've ever loved,
Speaking in tongues I almost understand.

At these crossroads of consequence,
Where pavement meets possibility,
I finally realize the truth of travel:
It's not the destination that transforms us,

But the courage to pull over,
Step out into the rain-soaked night,
And admit we've been reading the wrong map
All along.

At the highways of woes
The sky hangs low with leaden clouds
As travelers trudge with heavy loads
Their backs bent double, spirits bowed.

I've seen them come from distant lands
With eyes that speak of battles fought
Against the demons of their minds
And victories too dearly bought.

The asphalt stretches, cracked and worn
Like veins across an aging hand
Each pothole marks a tragedy
Each mile a grief too vast to stand.

Yet still they move with stubborn steps
These pilgrims on their solemn way
Collecting scars like precious coins
To spend on some far brighter day.

And I among them, notebook clutched
Record the journey's bitter toll
For at these highways of deep woes
I've found the contours of my soul.

For it is here, amid despair
Where hope shines brightest, strange to tell
And those who walk these broken roads
Might find their heaven through this hell.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes
Where shadows stretch long and thin,
I've traveled with blistered feet
And a heart heavy within.

Asphalt ribbons unfurl like grief,
Each mile marker a memory lost.
Yellow lines divide the living
From those who've already crossed.

Cars rush by like fleeting hope,
Exhaust clouding what remains.
I stand at the shoulder watching
As my tears mix with the rains.

At the highways of woes
Where strangers never meet eyes,
We all drive toward horizons
That recede before our sighs.

Yet sometimes in the breakdown lane
A wildflower breaks through stone,
Reminding weary travelers
That we never walk alone.

AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

Intersections of sorrow meet here,
Where tarmac burns black under noon sun.
Travelers with eyes fixed forward,
Knuckles white on steering wheels of regret.

Roadside markers count the fallen—
Dreams, loves, chances never taken.
The median divides what was
From what might have been.

I've hitchhiked these desolate stretches,
Thumb extended toward an uncertain sky.
Pickup trucks filled with ghosts
Pass me by without slowing.

At night, the headlights confess
Secrets to the guardrails.
We are all just trying to find
The exit that leads back home.

Someday these highways of woes
Will crumble back to dust and stone.
But for now, we drive on,
Mapping our heartaches across the earth.

At the highways of woes
I found myself wandering again,
Beneath concrete overpasses
Where pigeons nest in pain.

The tollbooths collect more
Than quarters and dimes—
They gather our sighs,
Our wasted, precious time.

Each lane change a decision
I wasn't prepared to make.
The GPS of my conscience
Recalculating at every mistake.

On these highways of woes
The billboards advertise relief
That exits always promise
But never seem to give.

I've driven through the night watches,
Past the wrecks of better souls than mine.
Still searching for that junction
Where suffering and hope align.

Perhaps there is no destination,
Only the journey's bitter taste.
At the highways of woes,
We are all just passing waste.

AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

At the highways of woes,
Traffic jams of sorrows converge.
Red taillights blinking like warnings
As emotions surge and merge.

I've seen travelers broken down,
Hazard lights flashing desperation.
Souls stranded between exits,
Lost in life's navigation.

The rumble strips speak in tongues
Of those who've drifted too far.
Guardrails bent from impact
Where dreams crashed like cars.

Rain streaks across windshields
Like tears across weathered faces.
Wipers pushing back the flood
In synchronized, futile races.

At the highways of woes,
I learned to drive through storms,
To follow the faded yellow lines
When darkness transforms.

Perhaps we're all just vehicles
Carrying precious, fragile freight—
Hearts and hopes and histories
On journeys that cannot wait.

At the highways of woes
I planted wildflowers in the median.
Defiant bursts of color
Against asphalt oblivion.

Cars rush past like years,
A blur of metal and motion.
Each driver caged in private grief,
Islands in an endless ocean.

The road signs promise destinations
That never quite appear.
Mirages of contentment
That dissolve as we draw near.

I've counted mile markers like rosary beads,
Praying for redemption at the next exit.
But salvation isn't found in leaving,
Only in learning how to exist

At these highways of woes,
Where humanity crawls forward
Inch by desperate inch,
Toward a horizon forever deferred.

Yet still I scatter seeds along the shoulder,
An act of revolution against despair.
For even on these bitter roads,
Something beautiful might grow there.

At the highways of woes

At the highways of woes

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself between the pages of a book,
To dissolve into the shadows of evening,
Unseen, untouched by judgmental eyes.

She yearns for invisibility's cloak,
A shelter from the world's relentless noise,
A moment's peace in solitude's embrace,
Where vulnerability need not wear armor.

In corners of rooms at crowded parties,
She builds fortresses of quiet observation,
Studying the dance of those who thrive
In spotlight's glare, while she retreats.

But hiding has its hollow echoes too—
The self, concealed, begins to question worth.
Perhaps in time she'll learn the strength
In being seen, in standing tall despite the fear.

For now, she gathers courage in small doses,
Emerging briefly, testing waters of exposure,
Knowing someday the need to hide might fade,
Like morning mist beneath a patient sun.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath quilted memories and childhood dreams,
Where monsters lurk but cannot touch her there—
A sanctuary built of silence and of screams.

The world demands too much of fragile souls,
Requires performance, smiles, and strength,
When all her bones feel hollowed by the wind,
And every breath extends beyond its length.

She crafts her absence like an art form,
Perfecting ways to vanish while still here,
A ghost among the living, half-remembered,
Transparent to the ones who hold her dear.

What glory in this disappearing act?
What freedom in becoming less than air?
Perhaps the self preserved in isolation
Remains more true than one worn threadbare.

Yet in her hiding, seeds of courage plant themselves,
Taking root in darkness, reaching toward the light,
For even those who master invisibility
Eventually long to shine defiant, bright.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From expectations hanging heavy as storm clouds,
From voices that demand more than she can give,
From mirrors that reflect what others see.

She seeks the shelter of anonymity,
Wrapped in the comfort of being overlooked,
A small creature burrowing beneath fallen leaves,
Protected by nature's indifference.

In hiding there is power rarely spoken of—
The quiet revolution of self-preservation,
The wisdom in retreat when battles drain the soul,
The healing found in temporary absence.

She collects herself in these moments of concealment,
Gathers scattered pieces of her fractured heart,
Rebinds the pages of her interrupted story,
Prepares the ink for chapters yet unwritten.

Perhaps tomorrow she will emerge transformed,
Or perhaps the hiding place becomes her home.
Either way, this shelter she has built
Stands testament to survival's sacred art.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Curled like a question mark against the world,
A secret folded into origami shapes,
Tucked away where prying eyes can't reach.

The universe expands without her voice,
And she finds comfort in this temporary death,
This shedding of her social skin, this rest
From constant navigation of others' needs.

The hiding places change but not the urge—
Behind headphones, within book covers,
Beneath blankets heavy as medieval armor,
Inside the labyrinth of her own mind.

What luxury in disappearance! What relief
In stepping off the stage mid-performance,
In letting masks slip from exhausted features,
In breathing air not shared or judged or measured.

Yet isolation's double edge cuts deep with time;
The hidden self grows hungry for connection.
She'll emerge when ready, on her terms,
Carrying her shelters within, invisible but present.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like autumn's final leaf clinging to its branch,
Reluctant to join the dancing descent,
The inevitable exposure on open ground.

Her hiding is an ancient art inherited
From grandmothers who swallowed their pain,
From ancestors who learned survival
In making themselves small against danger.

She practices invisibility in crowded rooms,
Dimming her light when it threatens to blind,
Speaking in whispers that barely disturb the air,
Leaving no footprints on memory's shore.

But what of the universe inside her?
The galaxies spinning between her ribs,
The supernovas waiting in her fingertips,
The wisdom of ages locked behind her eyes?

Perhaps her hiding is not retreat but preparation,
A chrysalis stage before magnificent unfurling.
For even those who master the art of absence
Eventually find the courage to fully arrive.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:

Yet in this hiding, she finds something clear—

The clamor of the world grows deafening wide,
Its expectations weighted, hanging low,
Demanding pieces of her soul to show
While inner wells of courage have run dry.

She builds her fortress out of quiet things:
Old books with yellowed pages, cups of tea,
The gentle rhythm as her needle sings

Through fabric, creating what can't yet be.
In hiding, paradoxically, she brings
Herself to light—at last, completely free.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From piercing eyes and tongues that cut like steel.
The weight of others' gaze too much to feel,
As if her skin had somehow turned inside.

She seeks the corners where the shadows glide,
Where silence wraps around her like a seal.
Not running from the truth, but what's not real—
Those masks and mirrors where her ghosts reside.

But hiding is not vanishing, you see.
It's gathering strength from roots that dig down deep,
It's finding constellations in the dark,

Rewriting stories only she can keep.
For in this shelter that she claims as ark,
She's not just hiding—she is growing free.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To vanish like the mist at break of day,
To shed the skin of who she has to play,
And rest where only stillness can abide.

The world has grown too loud, too harsh, too wide,
Its constant clamor will not stay away.
Too many voices telling her to stay
When all her instincts scream to run and hide.

In hiding there is wisdom often missed—
The turtle draws its head inside its shell
Not out of fear, but knowing when to rest.

The seed must bury deep before it swells.
The moon must wane before it can grow full.
Sometimes to hide is how we most exist.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself between the pages' seams
Of stories yet unwritten, untold dreams
Where no one sees the tears she's kept inside.

The cloak of night becomes her faithful guide,
As stars above send down their silver beams,
Illuminating paths that no one seems
To walk except for those with wounds to hide.

Yet hiding holds a strange transformative power—
The caterpillar in its dark cocoon,
The bulb beneath the winter's frozen hour,

The child within the womb—all hide to bloom.
So too, her soul requires this sacred bower
To shed what's false and find what's coming soon.

Yet hiding isn't always cowardice—

So when she wraps the silence round her shoulders,

Perhaps she's not escaping, but becoming
The quiet revolution of her choice.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

The world has carved its expectations deep,
Like canyons through the landscape of her heart.
She wears her armor daily without rest,

In crawlspaces between moments, she breathes,

These fragments of escape sustain her soul
When scrutiny has worn her spirit thin.

To hide is not surrender or defeat,
But sacred preservation of her core.
A revolutionary act of self-defense
When being seen demands a little more.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From cacophony of endless days,
To fold herself like origami birds
And tuck away from scrutinizing gaze.

The world, a stage of constant performance,
Demands her dance through spotlight's harsh terrain.
Her smile, a practiced curve of false delight,
Conceals the growing undercurrent pain.

In darkness, she discovers galaxies

The universe expands in solitude,

To hide is not a failure or retreat,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

She builds her walls of silence, brick by brick,

Beneath her skin, a universe expands—

Of oceans deep no sailor understands,

Sometimes the world demands too much to bear,

Like autumn leaves beneath December snow,

Has taken what it wished without control,
Leaving her hollow, scattered, undefined.

Yet in this hiding there is strength renewed,
A gathering of fragments once displaced.
In darkness she is slowly, wholly stewed
In essence of the self she hasn't faced.

Sometimes to hide is not to disappear,
But to become more vividly sincere.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From glaring eyes and judgment's heavy hand.
The weight of expectations amplified
By voices she can never understand.

She slips between the cracks of busy days,

She walks the world in self-protective haze,

But hidden things grow powerful in shade,

The woman who from daylight often strayed
Cultivates strength where silence is profound.

In hiding, she discovers what is real:

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

The world is loud with voices not her own,

Beneath blankets or books or starry skies,

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

She seeks the gentle corners of the earth,

The world mistakes her silence for defeat,

A woman forged in solitude's embrace,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
VEILED

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the shadows' embrace,
Where judgment's arrows cannot pierce her side,

She wraps silence around her like a shawl,
Draws curtains across windows to her soul,

Yet even as she shrinks from prying eyes,

And let the wounds of living be healed.

For hiding is both sanctuary and cage,
A paradox she lives on every page.

CHRYSALIS

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Curled like a question mark beneath the sheets,
As if the world outside has been denied
Its right to know her sorrows and defeats.

She crafts invisibility with care—
A science of not being fully seen.
She learns to breathe so quietly that air
Becomes complicit in her might-have-been.

The cocoon is not permanent, she knows.
Transformation requires this dark retreat.
Like winter bulbs beneath the heavy snows,
She gathers strength in seeming defeat.

Tomorrow she might emerge, wing by wing,
But today the hiding is everything.

ECLIPSE

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath the weight of expectations' tide.
To vanish like the moon behind the clouds,
Temporarily freed from human crowds.

In corners of her mind where none intrude,
She cultivates a sacred solitude.
Not running from but running to herself,
Placing her heart upon a higher shelf.

The world demands performance, constant show—
A theater of self she's come to know.
Yet in these moments stolen from the light,
She finds her truth within the gentle night.

Perhaps this hiding isn't weakness bred,
But wisdom seeking silence instead—
A necessary pause in life's long song,
To find where she's been right and where she's wrong.

DISAPPEARING ACT

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To slip between the cracks of busy days,
Like water seeping through the earth to find
A deeper current flowing secret ways.

The constant noise of living grows too loud—
The ping of phones, demands that never cease.
She longs to wrap herself in misty shroud,
A ghost among the living seeking peace.

Not every absence means that something's wrong;
Some spaces need defending to stay whole.
Like forests needing darkness for the song
Of nightingales to heal a weary soul.

The art of disappearing she refines,
Not vanishing completely, but enough
To gather scattered pieces of her mind
And smooth the edges of her roughened stuff.

She'll return when ready, stronger then,
Having hidden only to be found again.

SANCTUARY

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From prying eyes and voices sharp with spite.
To find a place where truth need not subside,
Where darkness feels more welcoming than light.

The world has grown too heavy on her skin—
Its constant judgment, endless harsh demands.
She seeks the quiet spaces deep within,
Where no one questions, no one understands.

Not cowardice but wisdom guides her steps

A sacred pause, not fleeing from the race.

For in this hidden garden of her soul,
She plants the seeds of strength that later bloom.
The hiding is not meant to swallow whole,
But give her space to heal, to breathe, resume.

And when she's ready, she will reappear,
Having found herself in disappearing here.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text:
And when, in the city in which I love you,
The streetlights flicker like uncertain stars,
I trace your shadow across cobblestones
Where our footsteps once harmonized.

The cafés still brew the same bitter coffee,
The bakeries still perfume the morning air,
But absence has its own gravity now,
Pulling at the edges of familiar streets.

I collect memories like fallen leaves—
A bench where we sat watching strangers pass,
A corner where you kissed me in the rain,
A window where your reflection caught the light.

The city holds you in its concrete arms,
Your laughter echoes down forgotten lanes.
I search for you in crowds of unfamiliar faces,
Knowing I'll find only fragments, never whole.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
Night finally draws its curtain across the sky,
I whisper your name to the indifferent moon,
And wait for an answer that never comes.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The buildings rise like prayers toward heaven's gate,
I wander through the maze of steel and stone,
A pilgrim seeking sanctuary in your grace.

This urban wilderness of noise and light
Becomes a temple when you walk these streets.
The subway rumbles like a distant chant,
The traffic signals pulse like sacred flames.

You consecrate these ordinary spaces—
A diner where we shared midnight confessions,
A park bench weathered by a hundred seasons,
A rooftop where the stars seemed within reach.

I carry maps inside my beating heart
Of places we have been and are to go.
Each intersection marks another promise,
Each alley holds the secrets of our souls.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I find myself alone among the crowds,
I close my eyes and feel your presence still,
As constant as the rhythm of this living, breathing town.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The fog rolls in from distant, hidden shores,
I feel the weight of ghosts upon my shoulders—
Memories we crafted, then abandoned.

The skyscrapers stand like sentinels of time,
Witnessing our story's rise and fall.
Graffiti whispers secrets on the walls
In languages only lovers understand.

I've mapped your absence on these concrete veins,
Marked intersections where we might have met
In some alternate universe where timing
Favored our collision, not our drift.

This metropolis of missed connections
Holds echoes of your voice in subway tunnels,
Reflections of your smile in rain-slick streets,
Fragments of what could have been but wasn't.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I stand beneath the weight of endless sky,
I wonder if you feel it too—this pull,
This gravity between two bodies, bound by invisible force.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The dawn breaks over tenements and towers,
I watch the light transform the mundane world
Into a canvas painted gold and promise.

The city breathes with countless lives entwined—
The vendor setting up his morning cart,
The nurse returning from her midnight shift,
The lovers saying goodbye at the train station.

Yet in this vast metropolis of souls,
It's you alone my heart seeks in the crowd.
Your presence makes these streets a sacred map,
Each landmark telling stories of our bond.

The bridge where first you held my trembling hand,
The garden where we sheltered from the rain,
The fire escape where summer nights we counted
Airplanes crossing through the velvet sky.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I hear your key turn softly in the lock,
The universe contracts to just this room,
Where distance dies and time stands reverent, still.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The winter wraps its fingers round the streets,
I find myself drawn back to haunted places
Where memories lie frozen, incomplete.

This urban labyrinth of glass and steel
Holds artifacts of what we were before—
A movie ticket stub, a coffee shop receipt,
A photograph beneath a broken door.

The city keeps its secrets like a vault,
Preserving moments we believed would last.
The park bench where we carved our initials,
Now weathered by the seasons that have passed.

I've learned that love is not a destination
But rather how we navigate the maze,
The choices made at every intersection,
The courage to continue through the haze.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I stand amid the chaos and the drone,
I realize that home is not a place at all,
But you—wherever you are—you alone.

Reflecting fragments of a fractured moon.
I stand on bridges contemplating currents,
How they carry everything away, eventually.

Street musicians play melodies
That sound like questions I can't answer.
Their open cases collect coins and regrets,
Small offerings to gods of chance encounters.

I've worn paths between significant landmarks—
The restaurant where you first held my hand,
The theater where your laugh outshone the stage,
The hotel where we said things we couldn't take back.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
Daylight breaks across unfamiliar rooftops,
I realize I am becoming a citizen
Of a place that exists only in memory.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The seasons change without permission or pause,
I find myself collecting fallen leaves,
Each one a day we might have shared.

Fog rolls in from distant harbors,
Blurring boundaries between what was and wasn't.
I reach for your hand in crowded markets,
Only to grasp at ghosts and possibilities.

The city speaks your name in strange tongues—
In taxi horns and slamming doors,
In the rustle of newspapers caught in updrafts,
In the quiet moments before dawn breaks.

I've mapped your absence across boroughs and districts,
Marked the places where you never were
But somehow should have been,
As if anticipation alone could conjure presence.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I finally stop walking in circles,
I discover the skyline has rearranged itself—
A new horizon built from old desires.

Kaleidoscope

The same light of longing shines from all eyes.
