To find within this bitter hour
The seeds of some forgotten power.

Shall I wasting in despair
Become a ghost of who I was?
A shadow drifting through the air,
A victim of time's ruthless claws?

The mirror shows a stranger's face,
Eyes hollow with remembered pain.
I search but cannot find a trace
Of who I was, who might remain.

Yet somewhere in this emptiness,
A spark refuses to expire.
It whispers through the wilderness
That ashes still contain their fire.

So though I waste in dark despair,
I'll gather fragments as they fall.
From broken pieces lying there,
I'll build a stronger, newer wall.

Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath grief's heavy tide?
Shall I let the thorns of care
Pierce the armor of my pride?

No! Though storm clouds gather thick
And lightning splits the troubled sky,
I'll not let my spirit sick
Lay its wings down, fail to fly.

For what is despair but fear
Dressed in sorrow's dark disguise?
A phantom that will disappear
When courage meets its hollow eyes.

So I'll rise from this dark place
Where shadows sought to claim my name.
With sunlight on my upturned face,
I'll kindle hope's eternal flame.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Count the hours that slip away?
Shall I watch the setting sun
Mark the closing of each day?

No, I'll rise from ashen thoughts
Shake the dust from weary wings
Breathe in life with hungry lungs
Taste what each new morning brings.

Shall I drown in memories
Of what was and might have been?
Shall I curse the darkened path
Where my footsteps once had been?

No, I'll forge through tangled woods
Find the clearing, find the light
Plant new seeds in broken ground
Claim the courage that is might.

Shall I wasting in despair
Drift like shadows on the wall?
Empty vessel, hollow eyes,
Watching as the teardrops fall.

Time, that cruel and patient thief,
Steals the colors from my sight.
Leaves me wandering through mist,
Graying day and endless night.

Yet beneath the frozen soil,
Sleeping seeds await their turn.
Patient in their darkened beds,
For the spring they quietly yearn.

Shall I wasting in despair
Miss the whisper of the breeze?
Or rise to meet tomorrow's dawn,
Face upturned among the trees?

Hope, a small but stubborn flame,
Flickers in the darkest hour.
From despair's cold ashes, see—
Life emerges, wild flower.

Shall I wasting in despair
Cling to broken promises?
Like autumn leaves that spiral down
To rest where winter kisses.

The clock hands move with steady pace
While I remain unmoved,
A statue carved from sorrow's stone,
By grief and time unproved.

The mirror shows a stranger's face
With eyes I don't recall,
They've witnessed too much suffering
To shine or gleam at all.

Yet somewhere in this hollow chest
A rhythm still persists,
A drumbeat faint but resolute
That stubbornly exists.

Perhaps today I'll simply breathe
And count that as enough,
Tomorrow I might find the strength
To craft from something rough.

Shall I wasting in despair
Build monuments to pain?
Erect cathedrals to my grief
Where only ghosts remain?

The world spins on its axis still
Though I have ceased to turn,
Frozen in this moment where
The flames no longer burn.

I've counted stars like rosary beads
Prayed to gods who never spoke,
Searched for meaning in the void
Where only echoes broke.

Yet water shapes the hardest stone
Given time enough to flow,
And even in the darkest night
The moon maintains its glow.

Perhaps in this unmaking
Lies the seed of what's to be—
The chrysalis must first dissolve
Before the wings break free.

Shall I wasting in despair
Become a prisoner of doubt?
A captive to the shadows that
Extinguish light throughout?

The clock ticks on relentlessly,
Indifferent to my plight,
While I remain entangled in
The tendrils of the night.

Each breath becomes a labor when
The heart has lost its will,
When purpose fades to memory
And passion's voice grows still.

Yet even in this barren place
Where joy seems far removed,
A single spark can reignite
What time has disapproved.

The phoenix never questions if
Its ashes warrant flight.
It simply burns and rises when
The moment feels just right.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Cause another's rosy are?
Be she fairer than the day,
Or the flow'ry meads in May,
If she be not so to me,
What care I how fair she be?

Shall my heart burn in the fire
Of unquenched, vain desire?
Shall I let my spirit sink
On the shores where others drink?
Time flows on like gentle streams,
Washing away broken dreams.
If she cannot feel my worth,
What care I for heaven on earth?

Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath the weight of air?
Shall I count each passing cloud
As my spirit grows less proud?

No—I'll rise against the tide
Finding strength I kept inside
For despair is but a room
Where shadows dance in partial gloom

I have walked through darker halls
Heard the echo of my calls
Bounce from indifferent, cold stone
Yet never truly walked alone

Shall I wasting in despair?
No, I choose the light to wear
Like armor forged in sorrow's heat
Making my becoming complete.

Shall I wasting in despair
Let my soul dissolve to air?
Shall I count the fallen leaves
As autumn's hand my hope bereaves?

The clock ticks on relentlessly
While shadows lengthen, haunting me
And memories once bright with joy
Now tarnished gold, a broken toy.

Despair, that thief of colored dreams
Is never quite what it first seems—
A teacher dressed in mourning clothes
Revealing truths that no one knows.

So let me waste not in the dark
But kindle hope's remaining spark
For even in the deepest night
Stars remind us of the light.

Shall I wasting in despair
Surrender to the thorned snare?
Shall I let my heart grow cold
As winter's story grows old?

The mirror shows a fractured face
A soul that's lost its former grace
The world spins on, indifferent, vast
While I remain chained to the past

Yet something whispers through the pain
A voice that calls my name again
Reminding me of who I was
Before despair became my cause

Perhaps in wasting we can find
The parts of us we left behind
And in the ashes of our grief
Discover paths to new belief.

Shall I wasting in despair
Become a ghost upon the stair?
A shadow of what might have been
A tale untold, a song unsung?

The ocean of my grief runs deep
With secrets I can no longer keep
They bubble up like ancient springs
Releasing all my borrowed wings

I wandered through the valley low
Where bitter herbs and nettles grow
And thought myself forever lost
A ship without a star to cross

Yet even in that darkened place
I found a strange and tender grace
For wasting taught me how to see
The strength that always lived in me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now departed hence.
Like autumn leaves that fall from gilded trees,
Your absence leaves me bare in winter's cold.
I held you once, so small within my palm,
Your fingers curled like petals toward the sun.
The years grew short, as all good things must end,
And now I stand alone upon this shore,
Watching your sail fade into distant mist.
What father would not weep to lose such light?
What mother's arms not ache with emptiness?
Yet in this grief, I find a stranger peace,
For you have grown beyond my sheltering wing,
To soar in skies I never dared to dream.
Farewell, sweet child, my joy, my everything.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Snatched like a petal in the storm's cruel grasp.
The cradle rocks, but emptiness remains
Where once your laughter filled these hollow halls.

I trace the ghost of you in morning light,
In shadows dancing on the nursery wall.
Your absence weighs like stones upon my chest,
A monument to what we've lost and gained.

The universe, in taking you away,
Left stars to guide my journey through the dark.
I search the heavens for your shining face,
And find you scattered in the cosmic dust.

Farewell, my child, my heart, my everything—
Though parted now by death's unyielding veil,
Your spirit flows like rivers through my veins,
Eternal as the tide that shapes the shore.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Sweet blossom plucked before thy summer's bloom.
The world grows dim without thy gentle light,
As stars fade fast before the breaking dawn.

I watched thee grow from tender, fragile seed,
To vibrant youth with dreams yet unfulfilled.
The promise of thy days, like morning dew,
Now vanished with the rising of the sun.

What words can soothe a heart so deeply torn?
What balm can heal the wound of thy departure?
I stand as monument to grief unbound,
A hollow vessel where once love flowed free.

Yet in this pain, I find thy essence still,
In whispered winds and gentle evening rain.
For though thy form has fled beyond my reach,
Thy spirit dances on in memory's grace.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The echo of your laughter haunts these halls.
I wander rooms where once your footsteps fell,
Collecting shadows of what used to be.

Time's cruel arithmetic has subtracted you,
Leaving remainder sums of memory.
The mathematics of this loss confounds—
How absence weighs far heavier than presence.

I plant your name in gardens of my verse,
Hoping that words might resurrect your smile.
But ink and paper make poor substitutes
For warm embraces that no longer come.

The universe expands between us now,
A distance measured not in miles but tears.
Yet somewhere in the cosmos of my heart,
Your constellation shines, eternal, bright.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
No longer bound to earth's constraining shore.
I release you like a kite to azure skies,
My fingers slowly loosening the string.

The cord between us stretches, does not break,
Through distance, time, and life's transforming change.
What was once flesh of flesh and bone of bone
Becomes a separate soul, distinct and free.

I stand upon the threshold of your flight,
Half-blinded by the brilliance of your wings.
What parent does not feel this bittersweet?
This pride and loss entangled like a knot.

Go forth, beloved, into worlds unknown,
Carrying pieces of my heart with you.
And know that in the chamber of my soul,
A candle burns eternal for your name.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A blossom plucked before your time to bloom,
The cradle songs unfinished, dreams destroyed,
As heaven claims you for its own too soon.

I held you once against my beating heart,
Your tiny fingers wrapped around my own,
Not knowing then how swiftly we would part,
The seeds of grief already deeply sown.

The silence now where laughter should have grown,
The empty spaces you were meant to fill,
These hollow rooms that never will feel home,
Without your presence on the windowsill.

Yet in this void, your spirit lingers still,
A ghost of possibilities untold,
And though my arms are empty, vacant, chill,
Your memory is mine to have and hold.

Farewell, sweet child, though parting brings such pain,
In some far place, we'll surely meet again.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My quill now trembles as I bid adieu,
To one whose light outshone the brightest star,
Whose absence leaves my sky no longer blue.

I crafted dreams from hopes and whispered prayers,
Imagined futures painted bold and bright,
Not knowing time would steal what love had built,
And plunge my daylight into endless night.

The world spins on, indifferent to my loss,
As seasons change and rivers find the sea,
Yet I remain, anchored to memory,
Of what once was and what will never be.

Perhaps in some dimension yet unknown,
Where souls released from earthly bonds may roam,
You dance among the constellations now,
Far from this mortal realm you briefly called home.

So go, beloved child, seek boundless skies,
Though here I stand with tears that never dry.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The autumn leaves now spiral to the ground,
As you depart for shores I cannot reach,
Where mortal footsteps make no earthly sound.

I wonder if the angels recognized
The treasure that from earth they chose to take,
Or if they simply saw a brilliant soul
Too luminous for this world to contain.

The books we never read, the games unplayed,
The wisdom I had gathered to impart,
Now sit like monuments to shattered plans,
Dust-gathering relics of a broken heart.

Yet gratitude still mingles with my grief,
For having held perfection, if but brief,
And in the quiet moments between tears,
I find that love transcends all mortal fears.

So sleep, my child, beneath celestial light,
Until we meet beyond time's distant shore.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
No longer will I guide your tender steps,
Nor watch your mind unfold like spring's first bloom,
As life's great journey calls you from my side.

The university that claims you now
Will shape the clay that I have roughly formed,
And other voices will replace my own
As wisdom's guardians upon your path.

Remember when we climbed the ancient oak,
Your small hand trusting mine would keep you safe?
Or how we traced the constellations' arc,
While crickets sang their midnight serenade?

Though distance grows between us day by day,
And independence is your rightful claim,
The invisible threads of blood and love
Remain unbroken through life's shifting frame.

Go forth, beloved child of my creation,
With courage as your shield and truth your light.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Though ink and parchment bear my sorrow now,
No written word can truly capture grief
That floods the chambers of a parent's heart.

I planted seeds of knowledge in your mind,
And watched them flourish under tender care,
Not knowing that the garden I had grown
Would wither in the winter of despair.

The plague that swept our village like a scythe,
Indifferent to my desperate, fervent prayers,
Has claimed you as its final, cruelest prize,
Leaving me heir to nothing but thin air.

Your mother weaves your shroud with trembling hands,
While I, your father, carve the wooden cross,
Our tears commingling with the April rain,
As we prepare to bear unbearable loss.

Yet even as we lay you in the earth,
I feel your spirit soaring, wild and free.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Though tender years have etched your face with light,
Time's cruel hand now severs what was joined,
As autumn leaves must fall when touched by frost.

I held you once, so small against my chest,
Your heartbeat like a sparrow's gentle wing.
Now distance grows between our souls, a chasm
That neither love nor memory can cross.

The echo of your laughter haunts these halls,
Where shadows dance in places you once played.
I reach for phantoms, grasping only air,
As grief becomes my constant, faithful shade.

What father's heart can bear such sudden loss?
What words can heal the wounds that time inflicts?
I stand alone beneath the watchful stars,
And whisper prayers that heaven keeps you safe.

Farewell, sweet child, my joy, my heart, my all;
Though parted now, in spirit ever bound.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My little universe of wonder gone.
The cradle empty, rocking to and fro,
As silent as the midnight's darkest hour.

How strange these fingers feel without your grip,
How hollow sounds my voice without your name.
The world turns colorless where once it bloomed
With all the vibrant hues your presence brought.

I scatter seeds across your favorite field,
Wildflowers that will bloom when spring returns.
Perhaps in their brief beauty I might glimpse
The fleeting gift your life bestowed on mine.

The birds still sing their morning melodies,
Though none so sweet as your remembered voice.
The sun still rises, sets with faithful grace,
Yet warms me not as did your gentle smile.

In every star that pierces through the dark,
I'll seek your light, eternal and unchanged.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Departed like the daylight from the sky.
No more your footsteps patter down the hall,
No more your laughter climbs the winding stair.

The books we read remain upon the shelf,
Bookmarked at tales we never did complete.
Your wooden horse stands frozen mid-gallop,
Awaiting hands that nevermore shall come.

I dream of futures stolen by the fates,
Of graduations, weddings never seen.
The grandchildren I'll never come to know,
The man you might have grown to someday be.

What strange arithmetic is this, that makes
A tiny grave weigh more than mountains tall?
How can such little years contain such love?
How can such brief a life leave such a void?

Yet in this sorrow, something still remains—
A thread of grace that binds us past the veil.
Farewell, sweet joy, until we meet again,
Beyond the stars where no goodbyes exist.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The cosmos calls you to its distant shore.
What strange and winding path you now must walk,
Beyond the reach of my protective grasp.

Remember how we traced the constellations?
Your finger pointing up with pure delight,
Connecting dots to form the ancient tales
Of heroes, beasts, and gods of long ago.

Now you yourself become a distant star,
A point of light that guides my darkened way.
Though galaxies may stretch between our souls,
No distance can diminish what we shared.

I send you forth with trembling, open hands,
As sailors once released their birds at sea,
To find new lands beyond the horizon's edge,
While harboring the hope of your return.

The world awaits your courage and your dreams,
Though part of me still wishes you could stay.
Farewell, bright spirit, forged within my heart,
Illuminate whatever skies you grace.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
No longer bound to earth's constraining clay.
The garden where I planted you with hope
Now yields a harvest bitter-sweet with tears.

I watch the seasons change without your witness,
The spring that brings no comfort to my bones,
The summer heat that cannot thaw this chill,
The autumn leaves that mirror my descent.

How strange that something small as infant hands
Could hold the weight of all my future days.
How strange that eyes now closed in endless sleep
Still see me clearly through the veil of time.

The world continues in its careless spin,
Indifferent to the breaking of my heart.
Street lamps illuminate the empty swing,
Where once your laughter challenged gravity.

I carry you in chambers of my soul,
A secret kingdom where you still reside.
Farewell in word alone, not spirit's truth—
For love transcends the boundary of breath.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A blossom plucked before its fullest bloom,
The morning light that faded far too soon,
Leaving shadows where once stood a boy.

I trace your memory with trembling fingers,
Across the empty spaces you once filled,
The laughter silenced, all your dreams now stilled,
Yet in my heart, your presence lingers.

The world turns on, indifferent to my grief,
As seasons change and stars maintain their course,
But time cannot diminish love's great force,
Nor bring to this persistent pain relief.

So go, my child, into that distant sphere,
Carry my love beyond this mortal plane,
And know that though we part in deepest pain,
Your spirit keeps you ever near.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Into the mist of memory you fade,
Like autumn leaves that dance and then degrade,
Returning to the earth that bore their buoy.

The cradle of my palm still feels your weight,
Though years have passed since last I held you close.
Your absence grows where once your presence rose,
A phantom limb, a trick of love and fate.

I wonder if the stars that guide your way
Are brighter than the ones that light my night,
If heaven's halls could match a parent's might
In loving you beyond the break of day.

Perhaps in dreams we'll meet on distant shores,
Where time stands still and sorrow has no name.
Until that day, I'll whisper soft your name,
And keep your memory safe forevermore.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The vessel of my hopes, my heart's delight,
Now sailing forth beyond my watchful sight,
Beyond the reach of grief that would destroy.

I planted seeds of wisdom in your soul,
And watered them with tears of love and care,
Now watch you grow too tall for me to spare,
Too whole to keep, too vibrant to control.

The universe conspires to set you free,
As stars must shine in their appointed place,
As rivers find the sea with rushing grace,
So you must find what you are meant to be.

I stand upon the shore and wave goodbye,
My pride outweighing sorrow's heavy toll,
For though you take with you a piece of soul,
You leave behind a love that cannot die.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The universe contracts within my chest,
As you depart from this familiar nest,
To worlds unknown, to futures to employ.

Did I not teach you how to count the stars?
To name the birds that sang at break of dawn?
To find your way when pathways seemed withdrawn?
To heal with gentle hands your childhood scars?

The clock ticks on with merciless design,
Transforming you from seedling into tree,
From question mark to bold identity,
From extension of my self to wholly thine.

I release you now with trembling, open hands,
A bittersweet surrender to the flow
Of time's great river where all children go,
Carrying my heart to distant, foreign lands.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The echo of your footsteps grows more faint,
As distance claims what time cannot acquaint,
The space between us stretching to destroy.

Remember when I taught you how to fly?
Your tiny hand in mine, we braved the air,
I never thought that moment would prepare
For this—the final, lasting goodbye.

The world awaits with open, hungry arms,
To challenge, change, and shape your tender heart,
To finish what my love could only start,
To test your strength against its harsh alarms.

A piece of me walks with you on your way,
Invisible but present as the wind,
The lessons and the love I tried to lend,
A compass pointing home should you ever stray.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's companion, now departed far.
Like morning dew upon a fragile toy,
Your presence fades beneath a distant star.

I held you once within these weathered palms,
Your laughter echoed through our humble halls.
Now silence reigns where once were sung your psalms,
And shadows dance upon the empty walls.

The world turns still without your gentle grace,
The seasons change but bring no sweet return.
I search the crowd for glimpses of your face,
While memories like autumn embers burn.

Yet in this loss, a truth I come to know:
That love released must have the space to grow.

CHILD OF MY SOUL

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A vessel formed of stardust and of clay.
Time's cruel current carries you away,
Beyond the reach of what words can employ.

I stand upon the shore and watch you sail
Into horizons painted gold and blue.
The universe expands between us two,
Yet something sacred binds beyond the veil.

What cosmic force first placed you in my care?
What wisdom saw our souls as intertwined?
Though separate paths we ultimately find,
Our stories weave a tapestry most rare.

In quiet moments when the day is done,
I feel you still—my daughter, my son.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A bittersweet departure marks this day.
Like petals scattered by winds that destroy,
Your absence leaves me hollow, turned to gray.

The cradle empty, toys upon the shelf,
Collect the dust of memories now past.
I wander rooms, a shadow of myself,
Clutching moments never meant to last.

How strange that grief and love should intertwine,
Like roots of ancient trees beneath the ground.
I drink this sorrow like the darkest wine,
And in its depths, your echoes still resound.

Though you depart beyond my mortal reach,
My soul will follow yours on distant beach.

CELESTIAL DEPARTURE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Whose spirit danced like firelight in the dark.
The cosmos calls you home, my brightest spark,
Returning stardust heaven did employ.

I watched you grow from seedling into bloom,
A miracle entrusted to my care.
Now whispered back into the waiting air,
Leaving nothing but this hollow room.

The universe expands with every breath,
Creating space between what was and is.
I stand between your birth and gentle death,
A witness to your brief but sacred bliss.

Perhaps all love is just a borrowed light,
A fleeting brilliance in eternal night.

INHERITANCE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The extension of my hopes, my dreams, my heart.
Like arrows from a bow, you must depart,
To build a world that time cannot destroy.

I gave you roots when you were small and new,
Then watched you stretch toward heaven's boundless blue.
The lessons written in your very bones
Will guide you through the forests and the stones.

Take with you all the stories that we shared,
The quiet moments when our souls laid bare.
Carry forward what deserves to live,
And leave behind what wisdom says to give.

Though distance grows between our separate ways,
Our blood sings harmonies through all our days.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The light that once danced in your innocent eyes,
Now dims as the distance between us grows wide.
I watch as you venture beyond my reach,
Into a world that I cannot protect you from.

The warmth of your small hand in mine,
A memory etched in the lines of my palm.
Time has stolen what once was wholly mine—
Your laughter, your wonder, your unquestioning trust.

The cradle now empty, the toys put away,
Silence inhabits the spaces you filled.
Yet in this parting, a strange pride takes root,
For you carry pieces of me as you go—
My lessons, my love, perhaps even my flaws.

So spread your wings, child of my making,
Fly toward horizons I'll never see.
Though my heart breaks with each mile between us,
I release you, my joy, my masterpiece, my legacy.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
As autumn leaves surrender to the wind,
So must I relinquish my grasp on thee.
The fruit of my labor, blood of my veins,
A vessel I filled with dreams and hopes,
Now sails away on life's tumultuous sea.

I stand upon the shore, waving goodbye,
As waves of time carry you from view.
The tiny fingers that once clutched mine
Now reach for stars beyond my giving.

What strange alchemy is this—that love
Can birth such sweet and bitter pain at once?
To nurture, guide, then watch you disappear
Into the mist of your own becoming.

The echo of your laughter haunts these halls,
Ghost-like whispers of what once was here.
Yet in this emptiness, a truth emerges:
In letting go, I grant the greatest gift—
The freedom for your soul to find its way,
Unshackled from the chains of my devotion.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My quill trembles as I pen these words to thee.
The universe that sparked between us fades,
A dying star whose light still travels on.

I sculpted thee with verses and with love,
Breathed life into the clay of metaphor,
Only to watch thee rise beyond my reach,
A poem grown wings, no longer mine to hold.

The ink that bound us dries upon the page,
Each stanza now a distant memory.
The rhythm of thy heart beats separate
From mine, which breaks with every measured line.

What cruel design is this—to create
Only to surrender what we've made?
Yet in this loss I find strange comfort too:
That beauty, once released, belongs to all.

So go, dear verse, dear child, dear fleeting joy,
Illuminate the darkness I cannot reach.
Though distance grows between creator and created,
My love remains, immortal as these words.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The hour glass empties, sand by precious sand.
I watch you slip through fingers spread too wide,
Unable to contain what was never mine to keep.

Remember how I taught you to skip stones?
The ripples spreading outward, like your influence now.
You were the pebble; I, merely the hand that threw—
The arc of your journey determined by forces beyond us both.

In dreams, I still feel your newborn weight,
Cradled against my chest, heart to thundering heart.
Now distance yawns between us, a chasm
Filled with years and choices and necessary partings.

The garden I tended blooms elsewhere now,
Your roots seeking deeper soil than I could provide.
I stand in the shadow of your growing greatness,
Both diminished and expanded by your absence.

So go forth, beloved creation, with my blessing.
Carry the seeds of our shared seasons.
Though winter comes for me, in you spring eternal—
My greatest work, set free from the confines of my love.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A constellation born from cosmic dust,
Now scattered across heaven's endless vault.
I trace your outline with a trembling finger,
Mapping stars that once formed my universe.

Death, that thief of common happiness,
Has stolen what was never meant to last.
Your small shoes by the door, untouched,
Collect the dust of days without your steps.

The silence in your room speaks volumes now—
A library of moments never to be written.
I wander through these hollow corridors,
A ghost among the relics of your being.

What strange arithmetic is grief,
That adds such weight while taking so much away?

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:

The ocean's breath became my own,

Time moved differently there,

In the phosphorescent glow.

I spoke with ancient creatures,

When morning broke the surface,

In my first sleep

That pulsed behind my eyelids

I wandered through the landscape
Of my childhood home,

That never existed,

My mother's voice echoed
From somewhere distant,
Calling me to dinner
Though she's been gone for years.

In my first sleep
I aged backward and forward,
A timeline accordion,
Folding past into future
Until I could no longer tell
Which memories were real
And which were yet to come.

The clock on the wall
Ticked thirteen times
And I understood, finally,
That time is merely a story
We tell ourselves to make sense
Of the infinite.

In my first sleep
I am a bird with broken wings,
Grounded yet yearning
For heights I once knew.

The moon pulls at my feathers
With gravitational longing,

Across midnight skies.

Beneath closed eyelids

Within the cosmos of my mind.

I reach for you across

In my first sleep
Memories transform to dreams,
And dreams to prophecies,

Meet in the neutral territory

When I wake, I'll carry

Sand from shores
I've never visited,

In my first sleep

Eternal visionaries
Breathing life into the storm.

We are dreamy creatures

The veil of mundane living
To which others have grown fond.

Our hearts beat to rhythms
Of songs not yet composed,
Our minds wander pathways
That mapmakers never disclosed.

We taste the colors of sunrise,
Feel the texture of the moon,
And carry conversations
With flowers that will bloom.

We are dreamy creatures
Whose feet may touch the ground,

Not lost but simply traveling

Fragmented and united,
Both broken and yet whole.

We are dreamy creatures,
Weavers of the impossible,
Alchemists transforming
Pain to gold, improbable.

Our hands reach through centuries
To touch what isn't there,
Bridging gaps between what is
And what we wish to dare.

We breathe life into shadows,
Give voice to silent stones,
And find within the emptiness
A place to call our own.

We are dreamy creatures,
Never fully understood,
Speaking in a language
Where words are more than should.

In this world of concrete,

Blurred around the edges,
Yet somehow crystal dear.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

responses.text:
STEEL MESSENGER

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A metallic whisper slicing night's velvet cloak.
Iron wheels spinning tales of departure and returning,
Leaving ghost-trails of memory in plumes of smoke.

Through sleeping valleys and dreaming towns it thunders,
A mechanical comet with windows all aglow.
Carrying strangers bound by temporary wonder,
As landscapes blur like watercolors in the flow.

We passengers, suspended between worlds and moments,
Cradled in the rhythm of this steel messenger's flight.
Our destinations hover like distant constellations,
While we hurtle through the canvas of the night.

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Piercing the veil between what was and what will be.
A silver needle stitching time with iron threading,
Binding horizons to the heart's geography.

MIDNIGHT TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Puncturing silence with its determined steel cry.
A constellation of windows against obsidian canvas,
Earthbound shooting star beneath the watchful sky.

It carries dreams wrapped in luggage and quiet conversations,
Whispered confessions between strangers passing through.
Each carriage a world of temporary intimacies,
Framed by the rhythm of tracks and midnight dew.

We surrender to motion, to the pull of elsewhere,
As farmhouses flicker like fireflies then fade.
The train devours distance with mechanical hunger,
Leaving nothing but memory in its wake.

How small we become inside this hurtling vessel,
Fragile bodies cradled in velocity and trust.
Yet how vast our minds as landscapes unfold before us,
And futures approach with each mile of wanderlust.

NOCTURNAL VOYAGE

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A mechanical phoenix with breath of steam and coal.
Tearing through midnight's fabric with precision,
Bearing witness to the sleeping country's soul.

Windows illuminate like fragments of fallen stars,
Each one framing a story, a face, a separate dream.
While outside, the world dissolves to shadowed contours,
And reality blurs at the edges, or so it seems.

The rhythm beneath becomes a heartbeat shared,
By strangers thrown together in this metal womb.
Temporarily united by the journey's purpose,
Yet each mind wanders in its private room.

I press my forehead to the cool glass barrier,
Watching my reflection superimposed on night.
A ghost-self traveling between what was and will be,
Held in suspension by this arrow's flight.

IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A determined messenger with nerves of steel and fire.
Cutting through the membrane of forgotten places,
Drawing threads of story with each singing wire.

The passengers sway in unconscious unison,
Rocked by the cradle of industrial design.
Some sleep with dreams accelerated by motion,
Others watch shadows race the moon's incline.

I count the stations like beads upon a rosary,
Each platform a prayer of arrival and departure.
The brief illumination of faces in windows,
Before darkness reclaims its territorial rapture.

How many journeys have carved these identical tracks?
How many hearts have quickened as destinations near?
The train runs on schedule through centuries of longing,
Piercing night with purpose, absolute and clear.

VELOCITY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A mechanical leviathan with hunger for miles.
Its belly full of strangers with disconnected stories,
All bound by iron rails and transient trials.

The countryside surrenders to our passing glance,
Too swift to capture, too beautiful to ignore.
Momentary tableaus framed by smudged glass:
A farmhouse light, a crossing gate, no more.

Time behaves differently at this rushing speed,
Elastic and strange, both condensed and expanded.
The past recedes faster than memory can hold it,
While futures approach before being fully demanded.

I feel the paradox of stillness within motion,
Of being nowhere while traveling everywhere at once.
The train carves tunnels through both space and being,
As we surrender to the journey, by chance or circumstance.

The moon follows loyally, refusing to banish

Strangers beside me drift in and from slumber,
Their faces illumined then swallowed by night.
We share this trajectory, souls without number,
Each carrying stories no other can write.

The tracks stretch before us like fate's rigid fingers,
Guiding our journey through darkness profound.
A memory of daylight persistently lingers
As we chase the horizon where dawn will be found.

Perhaps we are all just like arrows in flight,
Momentarily visible, cutting through time,
Before disappearing back into the night,
Leaving nothing but whispers and tracks as our sign.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

responses.text:
IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Cutting night's fabric with mechanical precision.
Steel vertebrae on parallel bones, departing
From what was known into clouded vision.

Windows flash like sequins on midnight's dress,
Interior lives briefly glimpsed then gone.
Each carriage carries dreams in various dress—
Some journey to, while others journey from.

The arrow flies unerring to its mark,
Destination pinned against tomorrow's dawn.
Passengers sway in rhythm to the dark,
Cocooned in transit, temporarily withdrawn.

We are all arrows shot from unseen bows,
Momentum carrying us where fate allows.

NIGHTBOUND

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Piercing velvet shadows with its sharpened light.
The passengers within, their journeys starting,
Become unwitting archers in the night.

Clackety-clack—the rhythm of departure
Echoes heartbeats of those leaving and those left.
The countryside dissolves in blurred rapture,
Of mountains, trees, and stars we are bereft.

We travel not just distance but through time,
Each mile markers our mortality.
The windows mirror faces, yours and mine,
Reflections caught in transient clarity.

We speed toward dawn with blind determination,
Shot from today toward tomorrow's constellation,
Never knowing if we'll hit our destination
Or become lost stars in endless navigation.

MIDNIGHT TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A metallic comet with human cargo,
Breathing steam dragons into night's black charting,
While inside, strangers drift in embryo.

The wheels speak ancient languages of motion,
Translating distance into heartbeat and breath.
Landscapes blur like memories across an ocean
Of consciousness, neither life nor death.

I press my face against cold glass divining
The invisible towns we thread like beads.
Behind us, phantom tracks keep realigning,
As history rewrites what it concedes.

We are all passengers of borrowed time,
Arrows loosed from yesterday's tired bow,
Seeking targets we cannot yet know—
Pioneers of darkness, sublime.

THE NIGHT EXPRESS

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Slicing through midnight's obsidian veil.
A mechanical serpent, forever starting,
Leaving behind a silver-whispered trail.

Inside this arrow's shaft, we dreamers huddle,
Strangers united by temporary flight.
Outside, the world becomes a starlit puddle,
Reflecting questions thrown into the night.

The engine pulls us forward, ever forward,
No pause for doubt, no time for looking back.
We're hurtling toward dawn without a wayward
Thought for what we've left along the track.

Sometimes I wonder if we're moving at all,
Or if the world simply slides past our view—
A canvas rolling backward, magical,
While we sit still, pretending to break through.

VELOCITY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A constellation of windows strung with light.
I count the miles by heartbeats, barely starting
To understand this journey through the night.

The countryside surrenders to our passing—
Farms and forests bow their heads in sleep.
While cities, ever wakeful, ever massing,
Flash electric promises they cannot keep.

We passengers are moments, briefly meeting,
Our lives intersecting for this fleeting ride.
The rhythm of the rails, constantly beating
The drum of progress, with nowhere to hide.

We shoot toward morning with blind conviction,
Never knowing if we'll reach the day.
Perhaps this arrow's flight is merely fiction,
And darkness is the only place we'll stay.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
Liquid Betrayal

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me like everything else,
Rolling down cheeks carved by sorrow,
Leaving trails of salt—evidence of pain
That evaporates too quickly to witness.

Even my grief refuses loyalty,
Dissipating into the air, becoming
Nothing but humidity and memory.
My sadness, so personal, so profound,
Refuses to remain as tangible proof.

I reach for droplets as they fall,
Trying to capture what's mine,
This manifestation of my breaking heart,
But they slip through fingers like promises,
Leaving nothing but phantom dampness.

Perhaps there is mercy in their departure—
These crystalline traitors that reflect
All I wish to hide from the world.
Still, I long for evidence of my humanity,
Some witness that won't desert me in my need.

Ephemeral Companions

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down my face in hasty departure,
As if ashamed of their origin, their purpose.
These liquid messengers of my pain
Become deserters the moment they form.

How strange to create something from your body
That immediately seeks escape,
As if my sorrow is too heavy to bear
Even for the very manifestations it births.
They splatter on floors, on clothing, disappear.

I wonder where tears go when they dry—
Do they return to the sky as rain?
Do strangers feel my grief in distant storms?
Or do they simply cease to exist,
Like so many feelings we try to hold?

Perhaps I should tattoo tear tracks on my face,
Force permanence where there is none,
Create a map of past sorrows that cannot flee.
But would that capture the gleam, the warmth,
The momentary truth of emotion made visible?

Abandoned Even By Grief

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They slip away, silver thieves in the night,
Robbing me of proof that I still feel,
That this hollow chest still harbors something human.

The universe grants no witnesses to my undoing—
Even water refuses to testify.
It falls, it fades, it disappears into cloth,
Into air, into nothingness.

When did I become so forsaken
That even the salt of my own ocean
Rushes to escape my shores?
What gravity pulls everything away?

I press fingers to dry cheeks,
Searching for evidence of the flood,
But my skin betrays nothing of the storm.
Perhaps I imagined the breaking.

If a heart shatters with no lasting tears,
Did it break at all? Philosophy for the abandoned:
We are left questioning our own pain
When even our grief refuses to remain faithful.

Transient Witnesses

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They depart like fair-weather friends,
Present only for the dramatic moment
Before seeking more hospitable terrain.

How curious that the body creates
These small, glistening betrayers—
Born of my deepest anguish
Yet so quick to abandon their creator.

I've watched them fall to earth,
These tiny messengers of my breaking,
Absorbed by fabric, by soil, by time,
Leaving no evidence of their existence.

Perhaps there's wisdom in their leaving;
They know what I have yet to learn—
That nothing of this pain should remain,
That even grief must eventually evaporate.

Still, I long for some permanent record,
Some faithful chronicler of this undoing.
Instead, I am left with dry cheeks
And the ghostly memory of wetness,
Wondering if I imagined the entire flood.

The Desertion of Sorrow

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They rush to escape the prison of my pain,
Falling, fleeing, finding freedom
In their graceful descent to oblivion.

What loyalty can I expect from water?
Fluid by nature, constant only in change,
They mirror the impermanence of everything
I've ever tried to hold within these hands.

I've counted on their company in darkness,
These tangible proofs that I still feel,
Yet they vanish like morning dew,
Leaving my face dry as desert stone.

Perhaps I should collect them in vials,
These reluctant children of my sorrow,
Preserve what refuses to preserve itself.
But wouldn't that be another futile grasping?

So I let them go, these disloyal droplets,
Accepting their nature to appear and vanish.
In their brief existence and swift departure,
They teach me what I need to know about letting go.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
Abandoned

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.

Rolling down cheeks carved by sorrow,
Disappearing into the fabric of my clothes,
Leaving no evidence of their brief existence.

Even my pain refuses to remain,

Before it too departs without farewell.

The universe collects my suffering
In invisible vessels, carrying away
The salt of my anguish, the water of my grief,
Leaving me hollow, a desert of emotion.

I reach for proof that I have felt something,
But my face is dry, my eyes clear.
Even in sadness, I am left with nothing,
Not even the comfort of my own tears' company.

EPHEMERAL MOURNING

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down my face in hurried escape,
As if ashamed of their own existence,
Evaporating before they can testify to my pain.

What loyalty can I expect from water and salt
When flesh and bone have already betrayed me?
My body produces these messengers of grief
Only to send them away without record or memory.

I am a rain cloud over parched earth,
Giving everything but retaining nothing.
The ground drinks deeply of what I cannot hold,
Leaving no puddles to reflect my broken sky.

Perhaps tears know better than to linger
In the hollows of a heart that keeps breaking.
They understand the art of letting go
While I remain, clutching ghosts of what was.

FORSAKEN DROPLETS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They betray me like shadows at high noon,
Vanishing into air, into cloth, into nothing—
Refusing to bear witness to this unraveling.

How strange to produce these pearls of sorrow
Only to watch them desert me so completely.
Each droplet born from the ocean inside
Rushing to return to some distant sea.

Is there no evidence I'm allowed to keep?
No proof of passage through this valley of grief?
Even my body conspires against memory,
Drying my cheeks before anyone can see.

Perhaps this is mercy—this quick erasure.
Or perhaps it's the cruelest trick of all:
To feel so deeply yet hold no tangible remnant,
To drown internally while appearing bone dry.

LIQUID DESERTION

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee like cowards from a losing battle,
Streaming down in hasty evacuation,
Dissipating into the atmosphere, traitors all.

What use is this salt-water currency
That spends itself before purchase of relief?
These transparent jewels that refuse collection,
These fleeting witnesses that leave no statement.

I wonder if the ocean feels this emptiness
As waves crash and return to anonymous depths.
Does it too feel betrayed by its own nature—
Forever giving, yet never truly touched?

I am learning the language of loss through this:
How everything, even expressions of grief,
Are temporary visitors to our experience.
How we remain alone, even in our weeping.

THE DESERTION

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They cascade away, these liquid betrayers,
Departing from the corners of reddened eyes
To journey down pathways of flushed skin.

How fitting that even my sorrow abandons me—
A final insult from a universe of departures.
These droplets, born from the pressure within,
Refuse to remain as evidence of what I feel.

I would capture them if I could,
Bottle this grief as proof I am still human,
Still capable of breaking open
Despite the scars that armor my heart.

But perhaps their leaving is the lesson:
Nothing stays—not joy, not pain, not tears.
We are merely temporary vessels
For feelings that were never truly ours to keep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
ABANDONED BY TEARS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,

These droplets forth to mark my face.

I am a desert now, parched and dry,
Where even sorrow doesn't bother to stay.
My emotions flee before they testify
To the emptiness that grows day by day.

So I stand alone, abandoned twice—

Left only with the cold advice

EPHEMERAL MOURNING

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.

When even my heart betrays me day by day.

Their journey down my face, then gone thereafter.

Perhaps it's fitting that nothing remains,
Not joy, not love, not even the proof of pain.
The universe teaches through these fading stains
That attachment brings nothing but chains.

So I'll learn from these tears that quickly depart,
To hold nothing sacred, to grasp nothing tight.
To let emotions flow through, not tear apart
This fragile vessel that weathers the night.

For if my own sorrow won't linger with me,
Perhaps that's the truest form of being free.

BETRAYED BY GRIEF

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They race down gravity's path, deserters in flight,
Leaving me bereft, alone in the night,
As if my sorrow isn't worthy to abide.

How strange that the physical signs of my pain
Are so quick to vanish, to evaporate and flee,
As though my suffering is too heavy to see,
Too burdensome for even salt drops to contain.

The world takes everything eventually—
Love, hope, dreams that once burned bright.
Now even the witness to my agony
Abandons me before the coming light.

Perhaps there's wisdom in their hasty retreat.
Perhaps they know that dwelling serves no end.
Maybe these tears, in their desertion complete,
Teach me that even grief must transcend.

So I stand empty, cheeks dried by time,
Holding space for a sadness that refuses to stay,
Learning that nothing—not even pain—is mine,
As tears, like all things, must go their way.

TRANSIENT COMPANIONS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They glisten momentarily, then vanish without trace,
As if embarrassed by the contours of my face,
Or perhaps they too have nothing left to hide.

When did my sorrows become so weightless?
Even the physical manifestation of my pain
Refuses to linger, to mark, to stain,
Leaving me wondering if my grief is faithless.

The world is full of temporary things—
Butterflies, sunsets, childhood dreams.
But I never thought my suffering brings
Such fleeting witnesses to my silent screams.

Perhaps there's mercy in their swift departure,
In the way they refuse to flood and drown.
Maybe my tears, in their wisdom smarter
Than my heart, know when to stand down.

So I'll honor their journey away from me,
These liquid messengers that briefly appear.
And learn that freedom sometimes must be
Found in letting go of what we hold dear.

DESERTION OF SORROW

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They betray me like promises spoken in haste,
Dissipating to nothing, leaving no taste
Of the salt-bitter anguish I cannot hide.

How curious that symbols of deepest despair
Refuse to remain as evidence of pain,
As if my suffering must not leave a stain,
Must vanish like breath in the winter air.

Perhaps the universe whispers a truth:
That nothing adheres to us, not joy, not grief.
All emotions, like seasons, are brutally brief,
And permanence is but a dream of youth.

So I stand alone with dry, burning eyes,
Abandoned even by the proof of my sorrow.
My cheeks a desert where nothing lies
Except the hope for a different tomorrow.

If tears won't accompany me on this road,
I'll walk it anyway, lighter somehow,
Unburdened by evidence of this heavy load,
Facing forward with a clear, tearless brow.

responses.text:

DESERTION

EPHEMERAL GRIEF

Has no loyalty to its creator's face.
Here today, then gone before tomorrow,
Departing without leaving any trace.

Am I so unbearable, so deeply flawed,
That even manifestations of my pain
Cannot bear to linger, cannot be awed
By the depth from which they came?

Perhaps there's wisdom in their swift retreat:
Nothing meant for healing should remain.

Movement is the antidote to pain.

So I'll learn from tears that will not stay:
To release, to flow, to let things go their way.

LIQUID BETRAYAL

As they race toward carpet, shirt, or ground.

When my own sorrow won't remain?

Refuses to bear witness to my pain?

Perhaps there's mercy in their swift departure—
A lesson wrapped in saline and despair:
That nothing, not even grief, lasts forever,
And freedom comes from what we dare not share.

So let them fall, these droplets of release.
Their journey teaches what my heart must learn:
That holding on will never bring me peace,

TRANSIENT COMPANIONS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They're born from oceans deep within my chest,
Yet once released, they quickly slide
Away from me—abandonment expressed.

How curious these liquid fragments are,
Forged in furnaces of my despair,
Yet acting like the most distant star,
Escaping me without the slightest care.

Perhaps they know what I've yet to learn:
That clinging only magnifies the pain.
That freedom comes when we discern
The value found in loss as well as gain.

So I'll observe these droplets as they flee,
Tracking paths down cheeks they'll never climb again.
In their desertion lies a prophecy:
That I too shall not forever in this state remain.

For if these tears, born of my deepest core,
Refuse to stay where darkness seems to thrive,

Than just to keep me company while I'm alive.

WATERLESS SORROW

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

responses.text:
I Hunted Words Of Skill

With bow of thought and arrows keen,
I stalked through forests of the mind,
Where syllables, like deer unseen,
Left subtle tracks for me to find.

Through thickets dense of doubt I crept,
Past shadows cast by failed attempts,
While metaphors before me leapt,
Elusive as the wind's laments.

I hunted words of skill and grace,
To capture truth too wild to tame,
Each phrase a trophy, each line a chase,
Each stanza bearing wisdom's name.

My quiver filled with verbs that dance,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A tapestry of thoughts inside her head.
Shadows dance across the wall,
While memories rise and fall.

The moonlight kisses her pale skin,
Illuminating battles fought within.
She counts the cracks upon the ceiling,
A map of time and all its healing.

The clock ticks on in steady beat,
A rhythm to her heart's retreat.
She crafts a world behind closed eyes,
Where loneliness no longer lies.

Her fingers trace the empty space,
Where once there was a warm embrace.
Yet in this solitude she finds,
The strength that comes when one unwinds.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Not broken, but reborn instead.

She lies alone upon her bed
With universe of stars inside her head
A galaxy of dreams untold
And cosmic stories yet to unfold

The silence wraps around her form
Like clouds before a gentle storm
Her breathing soft as evening air
A peaceful island, free from care

What visions swim behind those eyes?
What journeys through what distant skies?
Perhaps she walks on foreign shores
Or opens long-forbidden doors

The world outside may never know
The secret gardens where she goes
When twilight draws its purple veil
And consciousness begins to sail

She lies alone upon her bed
A poem herself, still to be read

She lies alone upon her bed,
A warrior with battles unwaged,
The ceiling's blank canvas overhead
Bears witness to her quiet rage.

Four walls that neither speak nor hear,
Contain a heart that's beating wild.
The strength of oceans rests in here,
In solitude, both fierce and mild.

Her fingers clutch the cotton sheets,
As if to anchor to this world.
While in her mind, she still competes
With dragons and their wings unfurled.

Alone is not the same as lonely,
This chamber is her sovereign land.
She reigns supreme, completely, wholly,
A kingdom built by her own hand.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A universe contained in skin.
The quietest revolution led
By fire burning deep within.

She lies alone upon her bed
Where ghosts of yesterday still tread.
The pillows damp with fallen tears,
Collectors of her nameless fears.

The curtains sway in gentle breeze,
Whispering secrets through the trees.
Her fingers clutch a faded note,
The final words he ever wrote.

Time stands frozen in this room,
A monument to love and doom.
The photographs face down in drawers,
Behind locked hearts and bolted doors.

Yet somewhere in the darkest night,
A tiny ember flickers bright.
For even as she lies there still,
Her spirit bends but will not kill.

She lies alone upon her bed,
But dawn approaches, hope ahead.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A constellation of freckles across her skin.
Neither awake nor fully asleep,
Dwelling in the space between.

The world outside continues its march,
Cars honking, people laughing, life unfolding.
Yet here, in this sanctuary of sheets,
Time suspends its relentless holding.

Books scattered like fallen soldiers,
Tell tales of where her mind has wandered.
Coffee cups, half-empty, cold,
Witnesses to thoughts she's pondered.

The ceiling fan spins lazy circles,
Hypnotic in its gentle sway.
Like her thoughts that spiral endlessly,
From yesterday into today.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A universe contained in solitude.
Not lonely, but complete unto herself,
In this perfect interlude.
