Memories she can't erase.

The pillow holds her silent tears,
As shadows dance upon the wall,
A symphony of nameless fears,
Echoes through the empty hall.

Her fingers trace the vacant space,
Where once another's warmth resided,
Time has not healed with gentle grace,
The heart that slowly has subsided.

She counts the cracks along the ceiling,
Mapping constellations in the dark,
Surrenders to the hollow feeling,
Of love that left its burning mark.

Dawn will break with promised light,
Yet darkness lingers in her soul,
Another sleepless, endless night,
Another day she must console.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A fortress built of quilts and dreams,
The universe inside her head
Is vaster than it often seems.

The ceiling is her open sky,
A canvas for her wandering mind,
Where possibilities soar high
And limitations fall behind.

Her solitude's not loneliness,
But sacred space to reimagine
The world with all its messiness
Transformed by her creative engine.

She crafts new worlds between each breath,
Populates them with her desires,
Defying both mundane and death
With hope that endlessly inspires.

This bed, her ship through time and space,
This moment, infinite and free,
Her heart, the most courageous place,
Where she becomes who she might be.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A warrior finally at rest,
The battles fought inside her head
Have left her weary, yet still blessed.

The scars invisible to most,
Bear witness to her silent strength,
No need to brag, no need to boast,
Of trials endured at any length.

Her body, tired from daily fight,
Against the world that pushed her down,
Yet still her spirit burns so bright,
Refusing still to wear a frown.

Tomorrow waits with challenges new,
More mountains tall that she must climb,
More proving what she can push through,
More conquering one step at a time.

So now she breathes in precious peace,
Collecting strength for dawn's demand,
When temporary rest must cease,
And she must rise to make her stand.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A garden grows beneath her skin,
Of wildflowers and thorny dread,
Of what's without and what's within.

The clock ticks forward, never back,
Its rhythm mocks her restless mind,
As memories, both bright and black,
Leave footprints she cannot unwind.

The ceiling fan spins endless rounds,
Hypnotic in its steady whirl,
Like time that heals but also hounds,
This aging, changing, growing girl.

Outside her window, life proceeds,
The world spins on without her voice,
While she attends to inner needs,
In solitude—not fate, but choice.

Tomorrow she may join the throng,
Of souls who seek connection's touch,
But tonight, in silence long,
She finds herself—and that's enough.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A ghost of fever on her brow,
The illness speaking in her stead,
Reducing life to here and now.

The walls close in, then drift away,
As consciousness ebbs like the tide,
What once was night now seems like day,
Reality and dreams collide.

A glass of water sits untouched,
Beside worn pages of a book,
Her plans and schedules all uncrutched,
Time passes with nary a look.

The body speaks in aches and heat,
A language urgent, raw and true,
Forcing her soul to retreat,
To heal what's broken, make anew.

In sickness comes a strange release,
From obligations, should and must,
An unexpected kind of peace,
When all that matters is to trust.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
Silent tears her only friends,
The weight of memories in her head,
A broken heart that never mends.

Moonlight spills across the floor,
Illuminating what's been lost,
The echo of a closing door,
The final, devastating cost.

She counts the cracks along the ceiling,
Tracing patterns in the dark,
Numb to every human feeling,
The ember of a fading spark.

Beyond her window, life continues,
Stars that shine and never care,
While time, relentless, diminishes
The hope she can no longer bear.

Yet in this solitude, a strength
Begins to form beneath her pain,
A quiet power, gaining length,
That whispers she'll rise again.

She lies alone upon her bed
Of wildflowers and morning dew,
The forest canopy overhead
Paints shadows in cerulean blue.

Mother Earth in gentle slumber,
Breathing life with every rest,
Dreaming worlds without number,
Cradling birds within her breast.

The wind, her faithful companion,
Whispers secrets in her ear,
Tales of distant mountain canyons,
And oceans she will never near.

Cycles of death and rebirth
Play across her ancient face,
The goddess of our fragile earth
Suspended in eternal grace.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Yet connected to us all,
The thread of life forever spread
From her rise to her fall.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A constellation of possibilities,
Thoughts like comets in her head,
Mapped across infinities.

Dreams unfurl like nebula clouds,
Vivid worlds behind closed eyes,
Where reality's rigid shrouds
Dissolve beneath imagined skies.

Her mind—a universe expanding,
Creating stories yet untold,
Worlds beyond our understanding,
Heroes brave and villains bold.

In this solitude, creation blooms,
Characters breathe and landscapes form,
Escaping mundane bedroom rooms
For adventures beyond the norm.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Yet travels farther than the stars,
Through the cosmos of her head,
Beyond all boundaries and bars.

She lies alone upon her bed,
The warrior's battle finally done,
The armor shed, the sword now dead,
A hard-fought victory grimly won.

Scars like medals cross her skin,
Each telling tales of fierce defiance,
The outer marks of strength within,
Forged through pain and self-reliance.

She fought the demons in the dark,
Both others' and her very own,
Left standing when the world turned stark,
Surviving storms she'd never known.

Exhaustion claims her weary frame,
Yet pride resides beneath the ache,
For she has earned her warrior's name,
And chosen which battles to take.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Not vanquished, but in victory's rest,
Tomorrow's wars still lie ahead,
But tonight, she's done her best.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A photograph clutched to her chest,
Of summer days long since fled,
And youth's sweet innocence at rest.

The sepia tones of fading time
Capture smiles now etched in wrinkles,
Loved ones lost to age's climb,
Their memory all that still twinkles.

Eighty years of life's grand play,
Compressed into fragile paper squares,
The children grown and moved away,
The husband claimed by time's affairs.

Her fingers, knotted now with age,
Trace faces with familiar love,
Each photo like a treasured page
From stories written up above.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Yet surrounded by a lifetime's ghosts,
The living memory of the dead,
The ones she's always loved the most.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
Thoughts like shadows dance in her head.
Moonlight spills across the floor,
Illuminating what she's longing for.

Silent tears trace paths unknown,
On a pillow where dreams have flown.
Memories whisper of yesterday's touch,
Of love that gave and took too much.

The clock ticks on in rhythmic beat,
Marking time with cold conceit.
While outside the world moves fast,
Inside her room, she grips the past.

She lies alone upon her bed,
With future paths left untread.
Yet in this solitude she finds,
The strength to heal fractured minds.

Dawn will break with gentle light,
Bringing courage after the night.
For now she rests in quiet grace,
Finding peace in empty space.

She lies alone upon her bed
A universe contained in flesh and bone
The ceiling's cracks form constellations
That only she can name

The sheets remember other bodies
Ghosts of warmth that haunt the cotton
She counts her heartbeats like rosary beads
Each pulse a prayer for something sacred

Outside, the city breathes and sighs
A million lives in motion
While she remains perfectly still
A planet fixed in orbit around absence

Her fingers trace invisible words
On skin that yearns for language
The stories she tells herself
Become the myths she lives by

She lies alone upon her bed
Neither sleeping nor awake
But dwelling in that twilight space
Where solitude becomes salvation.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Crowned with thorns of anxious dread.
Digital glow from screens nearby,
Paint her face with haunted light.

Notifications ping like distant stars,
Connections made but feeling far.
Scrolling through a life curated,
While her true self lies sedated.

She lies alone upon her bed,
With earbuds whispering in her head.
Podcasts, playlists, voices streaming,
Anything to stop the screaming.

Of silence that reveals too much,
Of questions that her soul won't touch.
In this modern isolation,
She finds both curse and liberation.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A generation raised on threads
Of virtual ties that bind yet break,
A paradox too real to fake.

She lies alone upon her bed
A warrior queen in temporary rest
Her battle scars invisible
But etched beneath her breast

The day's demands now silenced
In this sanctuary of sheets and shade
Where she removes the armor
That society made

She lies alone upon her bed
Not lonely, but complete
A moment stolen from the world
A victory, not defeat

The strength it took to carry on
Through challenges unseen
Now settles in her breathing
Deep, rhythmic, and serene

She lies alone upon her bed
Tomorrow waits beyond the door
But here, in midnight's gentle hold
She's sovereign to her core.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A garden's worth of books unread
Surrounding her like faithful friends,
Each spine a promise that extends

Beyond the walls that hold her fast,
To worlds where she is unsurpassed.
A traveler without a need
For tickets, only time to read.

The lamplight casts a golden spell,
As pages turn and stories swell.
She's walked with kings and beggars too,
Flown dragons 'neath skies of blue.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Yet countless lives fill up her head.
A universe in every tome,
Makes solitude feel most like home.

Alone but never truly so,
With characters that ebb and flow
Through consciousness like gentle tides,
In books, true magic still resides.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
Silent Solitude

She lies alone upon her bed,
Thoughts spinning like a carousel,
Memories of words left unsaid,
Secrets that only shadows tell.

Moonlight streams through parted curtains,
Painting silver on her skin,
In this realm of night, uncertain,
Where endings and beginnings blend.

The clock ticks forward, never back,
Companion to her whispered sighs,
As she traces patterns in the black,
With fingertips and tired eyes.

The universe expands above,
While she remains, a single star,
Contained within these walls of love
That crumbled, scattered near and far.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A universe contained in one,
Both empty and completely full,
A story finished, yet undone.

Awakening

She lies alone upon her bed,
A chrysalis of flesh and bone,
The ceiling's cracks map overhead
The paths her dreams have flown.

Her chest—a tide of rise and fall—
Harbors breaths like precious pearls,
While outside, beyond the wall,
The hurried world unfurls.

The sheets remember yesterday,
Creased with choices, joys, regrets;
Their cotton whispers seem to say
What consciousness forgets.

Her fingers curl like question marks
Around the answers never found.
Her solitude—both light and dark—
A kingdom without crown.

Tomorrow waits with patient hands
To lift her from this still cocoon.
Today she rests in twilight lands
Where transformation blooms.

The Weight of Absence

She lies alone upon her bed,
A ship adrift on cotton seas,
The ghost of touch still in her head,
A phantom ache that will not ease.

The indentation to her right
Remains unfilled, a hollow space,
Where once his body, warm with light,
Completed her in tight embrace.

The walls absorb her silent tears,
As clocks tick-mock the passing time.
The house too large by several years,
Since death stole him in cruel design.

Her wedding ring—a golden weight—
Still circles flesh that's grown too thin.
Half-emptied drawers in wait
For hands that won't return again.

She lies alone upon her bed,
And learns to breathe with half a heart,
Surviving in the life that's left,
A masterpiece now torn apart.

Digital Dreams

She lies alone upon her bed,
Illuminated by the glow
Of pixelated worlds instead
Of stars that twinkled long ago.

Her thumbs dance over glass and light,
Connecting to a thousand minds,
While physical touch, a distant right,
Becomes a luxury she finds

Increasingly abstract and strange—
A concept from another time.
As algorithms rearrange
The way we love, connect, and rhyme.

The blue light bathes her weary face,
A modern moon for modern nights.
In virtual worlds she finds her place,
Among the endless satellite

Of lonely souls who also lie
Alone upon their separate beds,
Connected by the digital sky,
Disconnected in their heads.

Renaissance

She lies alone upon her bed,
A canvas stretched in morning light,
The artist of her days ahead,
Awakening from restful night.

No longer does she wait for hands
To shape her purpose or her path.
The hourglass of shifting sands
Bears witness to her aftermath.

The mirror shows a face reborn,
Eyes bright with possibilities,
The chrysalis of grief now torn,
She stretches wings with newfound ease.

The room that once confined her pain
Transforms to launch her second flight.
The tears that fell like summer rain
Have nourished seeds of pure delight.

She rises from her bed, renewed,
No longer defined by what's fled.
Her solitude—a strength imbued,
A crown upon her worthy head.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
Through me, the path to sorrow's realm unfolds,
Where weeping echoes through the ashen air.
Abandoned hope lies crushed in bitter cold,
As shadows dance with demons of despair.

The city dolente, wrapped in endless night,
Where tortured souls cry out for mercy's hand.
No stars to guide, no whisper of delight,
Just footprints pressed in memory's shifting sand.

Dante's warning etched in stone and time,
A threshold crossed cannot be crossed again.
The weight of choices made in reason's prime,
Now carried forth through suffering and pain.

Yet even here, where darkness claims its throne,
A spark of grace illuminates the way.
For in the depths where none should walk alone,
The heart still beats, still longs for break of day.

THE DOLOROUS GATE

Through me lies passage to the grieving city,
Where ancient tears have carved the stones away.
I stand between two worlds without much pity,
The last bright threshold before night claims day.

Remember those who entered here before,
Their faces pale with knowledge not yet yours.
They too once paused before this heavy door,
Before they walked where no light reassures.

The city waits with patience born of time,
Its streets a labyrinth of lost desires.
Its towers built from consequence and crime,
Its rivers flowing where hope expires.

Yet something sacred lingers in this place,
A truth that only suffering reveals—
That even in abandonment and disgrace,
The human spirit bends but never kneels.

INFERNAL PASSAGE

Through me the way into the city of woe,
Where cobblestones are slick with fallen tears.
A journey few would willingly bestow
Upon themselves, this path of ancient fears.

The gates stand open, neither locked nor barred,
Yet hesitation grips the traveler's heart.
For what lies beyond cannot be disregarded—
A world where soul and suffering never part.

I traced these words upon the archway stone,
A warning and a promise intertwined.
For some must walk this passage all alone
To find what they have desperately tried to find.

The city dolente waits with patient breath,
Neither malicious nor particularly kind.
It simply is—beyond both life and death—
A mirror for the secrets of the mind.

DESCENT

Through me one journeys to the city of pain,
Where sorrow's architecture scrapes the sky.
The entrance seems so simple, so mundane—
A threshold crossed before you question why.

I've watched them come, these pilgrims to despair,
Some seeking wisdom, others running blind.
They rarely notice how the sweetened air
Grows bitter as they leave themselves behind.

The city dolente welcomes with open arms,
Its streets familiar though you've never been.
It whispers recognition, deadly charms,
Revealing truths you've hidden deep within.

Perhaps this journey isn't punishment,
But revelation's necessary path.
A sacred map, divinely heaven-sent,
To guide you through the aftermath of wrath.

BEYOND THE INSCRIPTION

Through me the passage to the mournful town,
Where Dante's footsteps echo still today.
I stand where hope and courage both bow down,
Where twilight never brightens into day.

The city dolente—sorrowful and vast,
A metropolis of consequence and fate.
Where present moments quickly become past,
And recognition always comes too late.

What draws us to these words carved long ago?
This invitation to descend and see
The architecture of our hidden woe,
The structures of our own iniquity?

Perhaps in walking through this ancient gate,
In facing what we fear and what we've done,
We find that mercy isn't always late,
That after darkness comes a different sun.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
Through Me to the City of Sorrow

Through me to the city of sorrow, where shadows dwell,
Where ancient tears have carved rivers in stone.
I stand at the threshold of what was once well,
Now fractured and hollow, a kingdom overthrown.

The gates creak with memories of laughter now gone,
Streets echo with footsteps that no longer tread.
I enter this labyrinth at breaking of dawn,
Carrying burdens of words left unsaid.

Through me to the city where hope abandoned all,
Where flowers once bloomed in gardens of light.
Now petals lie withered against the cold wall,
As darkness consumes what was precious and bright.

Yet even in sorrow, beauty remains,
In ruins that whisper of what came before.
Through me to the city where nothing sustains,
Except the raw truth at its desolate core.

Descent

Through me lies the path to the grieving city,
Where cobblestones weep beneath shuffling feet.
The air hangs heavy with unspoken pity,
As souls wander streets that never complete.

I've crossed this threshold a thousand times before,
Each journey leaving scars upon my heart.
The city's walls remember ancient lore,
Of lives entangled, then brutally apart.

Dante knew this passage all too well,
His footprints still visible in the dust.
What wisdom comes from creating one's hell?
What lessons learned when dreams turn to rust?

The city dolente—sorrowful and deep,
A labyrinth of memories we keep locked away.
Through me the path winds downward, steep,
Into shadows where lost emotions play.

And yet I walk this road again, again,
For in the city's heart, truth finally speaks.

Lamentations of Stone

Through me one enters the sorrowful city,
Where ancient stones weep tears of forgotten rain.
The gates stand open—a terrible pity—
Inviting travelers to witness its pain.

I wandered once through those crumbling arches,
Where time had stilled and mercy had fled.
Beneath the weight of eternal marches,
The living walked among the unsaid dead.

Dante's warning echoes through centuries,
A truth unchanged since his quill touched page.
The city dolente holds its mysteries,
Preserved in grief, untouched by age.

What hope remains in streets of lamentation?
What solace found where joy has taken flight?
Perhaps in darkness lies illumination—
The stars shine brightest in the deepest night.

So enter if you must this realm of sorrow,
But carry light within your trembling hand.

Dolent Passage

Through me one passes to the city of woe,
A realm where sunlight fears to cast its glow.
I stood before its gates, trembling, alone,
The wind a whisper, cold as ancient stone.

Dante's warning carved into my mind,
Abandoning all hope, leaving self behind.
Yet something pulled me forward, step by step,
Into those streets where only shadows crept.

The city dolente—its name a truth,
A place where sorrow steals eternal youth.
Its buildings lean like mourners at a grave,
Its rivers flow with tears none could save.

But in this darkness, strange to comprehend,
I found reflection, not an empty end.
For cities built of grief still shelter life,
And teach us how to bear our mortal strife.

So through these gates I journeyed, changed, returned,
With wisdom that in sorrow's depths I learned.

The Sorrowful City

Through me one enters the sorrowful city—
Words etched in stone above gates standing tall.
I pause before them, feeling something gritty
Catch in my throat as shadows start to fall.

What lies beyond this threshold of despair?
What lessons wait within those ancient walls?
I feel the weight of centuries in the air,
As Dante's warning through the ages calls.

The city dolente beckons with strange grace,
Its streets a maze of memories and pain.
Within its bounds, time moves at different pace,
As past and present intertwine like rain.

Perhaps we all must enter such a place,
To understand the depths that dwell within.
To face the shadows we so often chase,
And recognize our suffering as kin.

So I step forward, crossing boundaries set,
Into the city where all truths are met.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
Through me the path to the woeful city lies,
Where Dante's vision haunts the shadowed gate.
I stand before the entrance to demise,
Where hope dissolves and sorrows congregate.

The ancient words carved deep in memory's stone,
Echoing through centuries of human dread.
Each syllable a weight I've always known,
Each verse a map to where the damned are led.

Yet in this darkness, strange lights sometimes bloom,
Flowers of understanding, rare and wild.
Wisdom grows deepest in the fertile gloom,
Where pain and beauty stand reconciled.

So I descend, eyes open to the night,
Seeking in suffering a different light.

DOLENTE

Through me one enters the city of pain—
words etched in stone above an ancient gate.
I trace them with my fingertips again,
wondering what sorrows might await.

The language of the dead still speaks to me,
its melody both beautiful and strange.
Italian syllables like skeleton keys
unlocking doors I fear to rearrange.

What city calls me to its broken heart?
What grief demands witness in this hour?
Perhaps it's mine—the ruins torn apart
by time's indifferent, crushing power.

I step across the threshold, breath held tight.
The city of my wounds gleams in the night,
a constellation of what's lost and found.
I walk its streets. I learn its secret sound.

THE SORROWFUL CITY

Through me the way into the grieving town,
Where ancient stones weep tears of yesterday,
Where broken hearts and spirits tumble down
Into the depths where sunlight cannot stay.

I heard the warning Dante left behind—
Abandon hope, you who would enter here—
Yet still I venture with an open mind
Into the labyrinth of human fear.

The city dolente beckons with its song,
A melody of suffering and grace.
Perhaps in pain we finally belong,
Perhaps in darkness we might find our place.

For what is sorrow but the shadow cast
By joy's bright light upon the soul at last?
Through me, through you, the pathway always leads
To cities built from our most human needs.

PASSAGE

Through me one journeys to the city of sorrow,
where cobblestones are slick with unshed tears.
I did not choose to be this dark threshold,
this gateway to accumulated fears.

The language of the dead is surprisingly gentle—
Italian syllables like water over stone.
Città dolente: how the words themselves tremble,
carrying weight no living tongue has known.

I've stood before this entrance many times,
hesitating at the precipice of grief.
Sometimes I turn away, seeking lighter climes,
sometimes I enter, beyond all belief.

What strange cartography maps suffering's terrain?
What compass guides us through these shadowed streets?
Perhaps we need no guide but our own pain,
no map except the wounds beneath our feet.

INFERNO REVISITED

Through me the way into the suffering city,
Through me the way to eternal pain,
Through me the way among the lost people.

Dante's warning echoes through centuries,
Yet still I stand before these ancient gates,
Drawn to darkness like moth to flame.

What wisdom waits within those walls of woe?
What truth lies hidden in the depths of hell?
Perhaps it's only there we truly know
The boundaries of what it means to be human.

So I will walk where Virgil once led Dante,
Not as poet or prophet, but as witness.
I'll count the circles, name the suffering,
Trace my finger along each scar and story.

For isn't every heart a città dolente?
A city built of joy and grief entwined?
And don't we all, in time, pass through its gates,
Seeking meaning in the shadows we find?

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
DESCENT

Per me si va nella città dolente—
Through me the way into the suffering city.
I stand at the threshold of my own making,
where shadows stretch like fingers across stone,
and echoes return as whispers of regret.

The gates of my personal inferno swing wide,
hinges groaning beneath the weight of memory.
What circles await below? What contrapasso
for the sins I've carried like stones in my pockets,
pulling me deeper into these dark waters?

Dante knew the architecture of damnation—
each level a reflection of our broken hearts.
I too have mapped my transgressions in concentric rings,
each step downward a return to something essential,
each pain a recognition of what I've always known.

Yet even in descent, there are stars above.
Even in suffering, a strange sweetness persists.
The città dolente holds not just punishment
but the promise that to journey through darkness
is to begin the long ascent toward light.

THE GATES OF SORROW

"Per me si va nella città dolente"
The words inscribed above the shadowed gate
Where hope dissolves like morning mist at dawn
And souls proceed to meet their bitter fate.

I too have wandered through such darkened paths,
Where memory's thorns tear at the flesh of time,
Where voices echo from the distant past,
Like broken bells that struggle still to chime.

The city of sorrow stands eternal,
Built stone by stone from choices we regret,
Its spires reach toward a heaven distant,
Its foundations in the tears we've wept.

Yet even in this landscape of lament,
Where pain blooms like flowers after rain,
There dwells a strange and unexpected grace—
The knowledge that we feel because we've loved,
We grieve because we dared to dream at all.

So let me walk these streets of lamentation,
And find within their winding ways some truth,
For only those who've known the city's depths
Can truly value sunlight's gentle touch.

INFERNAL CARTOGRAPHY

Through me lies passage to the grieving city
where ancient words carve doorways into dread.
I trace Dante's footprints with trembling fingers,
map the contours of a hell I've come to know.

This morning, I woke with those words upon my tongue,
tasting of ash and centuries, a borrowed ache.
The city dolente rises in my mind's eye—
not Florence, not Rome, but the architecture
of all we've built from suffering and regret.

How strange to find beauty in such testament,
to witness how pain, precisely rendered,
transforms to art that endures beyond its maker.
The poet descended through nine circles
to find his way back to the stars.

Perhaps we all must journey downward
before we learn to rise again.
Each step through grief's labyrinthine streets
a necessary passage, each torment
a station on the path to something greater.

Per me si va—through me the way unfolds.
I am both entrance and traveler,
both city and citizen, both poem and poet,
charting the geography of loss
to find, at last, my way back home.

ABANDON

"Per me si va nella città dolente"
Through me the way to sorrow's dwelling place—
I've carried these words like stones in my pocket,
rubbing them smooth with worried fingers.

What city waits beyond the gates of myself?
What souls wander there, abandoned to their grief?
I too have inscribed above my heart's entrance:
Abandon all hope, ye who enter here.

The suffering city is not so far from home.
It rises from the mist each morning,
its towers built from disappointments,
its streets paved with broken promises.
I am its reluctant citizen, its weary tourist,
its mapmaker and its lost wanderer.

Dante knew of circles, knew how pain
spirals downward, how we descend
through layers of our own making.
But he also knew of ascension,
of light penetrating even the deepest dark.

Perhaps this is why his words endure—
they mark not just the entrance to despair
but also the beginning of the journey back,
the first step toward stars we'd forgotten
we had the right to claim as our own.

TRANSLATIONS OF DESCENT

Per me si va nella città dolente.
Through me the way into the suffering city.
Through me the passage to eternal pain.
Through me among the people lost forever.

How many ways to translate grief?
How many languages for our descent?
I have walked through portals of my own devising,
entered rooms where sorrow hangs like tapestries,
where regret collects in corners like dust.

Dante's inferno was a perfect circle,
its architecture precise as mathematics.
My own hell is less ordered, more modern—
a sprawling metropolis with unmarked streets,
subway lines that lead to unexpected stations.

Yet I recognize something in those ancient words,
a truth that bridges centuries and tongues:
we all construct our cities of lament,
we all inscribe our warnings above the gate,
we all proceed, despite knowing what awaits.

Perhaps the true translation isn't in the words
but in the journey itself, the willing step
beyond the threshold, the courage to descend
into whatever darkness calls our name,
trusting that even there, we might find our way.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
THROUGH ME

Through me the path to sorrow's dwelling lies,
Where ancient stones weep tears of long despair.
I stand between the light and shadow's lair,
A threshold crossed by those whom fate denies.

The city dolent waits with open arms,
Its streets are paved with broken promises,
Its towers built from silent, swallowed screams.
The air is thick with long-forgotten charms.

Dante once walked these corridors of pain,
His verses etched in memory's fragile walls.
I hear his whispers echo through the rain:
"Abandon hope, yet know your suffering calls
A deeper truth from darkness to remain."

Through me, the wounded city breathes again.

DOLENT CITY

Into the grieving city I descend,
Where sorrow's architecture scrapes the sky.
The gates swing wide, no sentinel to tend
The boundary where the living fear to lie.

Dante's warning echoes through the years—
These streets I walk are paved with old regret.
The buildings rise like monuments to tears,
Constructed from the pain we can't forget.

Yet in this place of shadows, strange to tell,
A beauty blooms like flowers through the stone.
For suffering carves cathedrals in the shell
Of hearts that thought they'd harden or atone.

The dolent city teaches as I roam:
In deepest grief, we find our truest home.

INFERNAL PASSAGES

Through me one enters the city of woe,
Where cobblestones are laid with lost desires.
I carry Dante's torch as embers glow
Illuminating paths that spiral down.

The dolent city hums a mournful tune,
Its citizens wear masks of past mistakes.
The air hangs heavy like a dark monsoon,
While time stands still in grief's eternal lakes.

I wander streets where language finds its end,
Where words dissolve before they touch the tongue.
The buildings lean as if about to bend
And break beneath the weight of songs unsung.

Yet even here, where hope seems but a ghost,
I find within these walls what matters most—
The courage to descend, to face, to see
The dolent city waiting deep in me.

PASSAGE

Through me lies passage to the grieving town,
Where shadows dance on walls of weathered stone.
The ancient words of Dante tumble down
Across the centuries to chill the bone.

I stand before these gates and hesitate—
The dolent city calls with siren song.
What sorrows wait beyond this rusted gate?
What wisdom hides where suffering belongs?

Perhaps we all must journey through such doors,
To taste the bitter fruit of knowledge grown
In gardens where our deepest anguish pours
Its waters over seeds of truth long sown.

So enter I this realm of sweet lament,
For only through the darkness, light is sent.
The city dolent teaches as we fall:
To understand all pain is to know all.

LAMENTATIONS OF THE GATEKEEPERS

Through me one journeys to the city of pain—
Its spires reaching toward an ashen sky,
Its streets a labyrinth of old disdain
Where echoes of forgotten souls still sigh.

I am the threshold, neither here nor there,
A liminal space between hope and despair.
The dolent city's keeper, worn and bare,
Watching pilgrims pass with vacant stare.

Dante knew these walls, these crumbling stairs,
These avenues where mercy comes to die.
The weight of human folly heavy bears
On those who seek to question how and why.

Yet beauty dwells within this mournful place—
A strange, austere, and unexpected grace.
For in the city dolent, truth reveals
What brighter realms so carefully conceals.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I am the child of dust and determination.

My first breath drawn from air thick with desperation.

The scale of my birth weighed heavy with irony—

My cries joined the chorus of empty stomachs,

They named me Resilience,

The milk I sought came intermittently,
Like foreign aid—well-meaning but insufficient.

Yet I grew, as children somehow do,
In the most hostile of gardens.
My roots finding water where others saw only sand,
My spirit greening despite the drought of opportunity.

I am not your tragedy narrative.
I am the proof that even in famine,
Humanity's most persistent seed—hope—
Finds a way to flourish.

Born in the famine struck Africa
Where vultures circle patient as prayers

And count blessings in grains of millet

My mother's eyes—deep wells of memory
Recall green seasons before I existed
When bellies were full and laughter came easy
Before the sky turned its back on our pleas

I carry emptiness like an heirloom
A hollow space where childhood should be
Yet somehow this absence shapes me stronger
This hunger carves me into something fierce

The world sees only what's missing
Not how we transform lack into abundance
How we distill joy from mere existence
How we dance when there is no music

Born of famine yet never famished in spirit
I am the impossible bloom in the desert
The testimony that life persists
Even when death seems the easier choice

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I emerged from my mother's womb
Already understanding scarcity—

The elders said I arrived with old eyes,

My playground: ochre dust and stone.

I learned that dignity cannot be rationed,

From the throats of those with nothing left to lose.

They photographed our hollowed cheeks,
But missed our midnight stories,
The way we held each other through fever dreams,
The mathematics of sharing one meal among many.

I was born where life seems impossible,
Yet here I stand, possible.

BETWEEN WORLDS

Born in the famine struck Africa,

MOTHER CONTINENT

DROUGHT'S DAUGHTER

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Homer poured, in thousand wrote.'

responses.text:
Ancient Ink

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
His epic tales on time's vast sea.
From blind eyes, visions remote,
Immortalized for eternity.

Achilles' rage and Hector's fall,
Odysseus' journey home so long.
The wooden horse, Troy's crumbling wall,
All captured in undying song.

The wine-dark sea, the rosy dawn,
The gods who played with mortal lives.
Heroic deeds forever drawn
In verses where the past survives.

A thousand poets since have drunk
From Homer's cup, his ancient well.
Their own souls into words now sunk,
New stories they were born to tell.

So Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
And we who follow drink his wine.
Each word a star, each line a note,
In constellations deemed divine.

The Bard's Legacy

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
Sacred nectar from his mind.
Civilizations rise and float
On seas of verse he left behind.

Blind eyes seeing clearer truth
Than those who walked in daylight's glare.
Tales of glory, tales of youth,
Of gods and heroes laid bare.

From his lips the stories flowed,
Like honey mixed with bitter wine.
Across the centuries they've glowed,
Each word a torch in time's design.

The thousand wrote with borrowed quill,
Each adding to the tapestry.
Their voices echo Homer still,
In endless literary ancestry.

For what is writing but the soul
Poured out in drops of midnight ink?
The fractured heart made newly whole,
The bridge on which all thoughts can link.

Homer poured, the thousand wrote,
And still we drink from ancient streams.
Each poem a paper-crafted boat,
Sailing on our collective dreams.

Echoes of Epic

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
The wine of wisdom, aged and true.
Each syllable a wooden boat,
Sailing seas of midnight blue.

Blind eyes seeing beyond sight,
Painting worlds with only voice.
His stories blazed through ancient night,
Making mortals and gods rejoice.

The clash of bronze, the widow's tear,
The homeward journey, long delayed.
His words make distant worlds appear,
In minds where wonder hasn't strayed.

A thousand hands since took the flame,
Passing torches through the dark.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'An account of books 16-19 of the Iliad by Homer.'

responses.text:
THE RAGE OF PATROCLUS

Armed in the gleaming bronze of swift Achilles,
Patroclus strides forth, a borrowed lion's skin,
To push back Trojan flames from Argive ships.
The gods watch, scales tilted in fatal balance.

How many heroes fall beneath his spear?
Sarpedon, Zeus's son, breathes his last,
While Father Zeus lets crimson raindrops fall.
Glory and doom entwined in mortal dance.

Hector and Apollo—divine conspiracy—
Strip away armor, dignity, and life.
Patroclus falls, prophecy on his lips,
As darkness swallows light at battle's edge.

Achilles' cry splits heaven's vault asunder,
Thetis weeps silver tears into the sea,
As messengers bear news of friendship severed,
And vengeance blooms in hearts once filled with joy.

BRONZE CHRONICLES

Between the ships and Troy's unyielding walls,
Where dust clouds rise from chariots' spinning wheels,
The Argives falter, pressed by Hector's might,
While great Achilles nurses wounded pride.

Patroclus dons the armor of his friend,
A fateful choice that spins the thread of doom.
He drives the Trojans back in glorious rout
Until Apollo's hand strikes from his brow
The helmet bright, exposing mortal flesh.

The corpse contested, Ajax stands his ground,
As messengers bear tidings dark and grim
To where Achilles waits, unknowing yet.
His mother rises from the foaming deep
To comfort rage with promise of new arms.

Across the battlefield, night draws its veil,
As gods and men prepare for dawn's red work.

THE WEIGHT OF BRONZE

I sing of borrowed armor and its cost,
Of friendship stronger than the bonds of blood.
Patroclus rises where Achilles sits,
A shadow warrior in blazing light.

The Trojans flee before reflected glory,
Believing godlike Achilles storms their ranks.
But hubris drives the substitute too far,
Beyond the bounds that friendship set in place.

The corpse lies naked on the churning plain,
While wolves and jackals fight to claim the prize.
A mother's grief transforms to iron resolve;
New armor forged in elemental fire.

And in the Argive camp, a wailing rises—
Not just for one man's death, but for the chain
Of vengeance, loss, and fury yet to come,
As Troy's last days tick down like dying hearts.

DIVINE MACHINERY

The gods play chess with bronze-clad mortal pawns
Across the blood-soaked fields of windy Troy.
Zeus watches as his son meets destined death,
While Hera schemes and Thetis mourns anew.

Patroclus, wrapped in borrowed lion's hide,
Forgets himself in victory's sweet taste.
Three times he charges Troy's unbroken walls,
Three times Apollo pushes him away.

The fourth attempt invites the archer's wrath—
A god's hand strikes, a mortal's armor falls.
Euphorbus wounds, and Hector claims the kill,
Though victory was never his alone.

And as the armies clash around the corpse,
Achilles stands unknowing by his ships,
Until the news arrives on grief's dark wings,
And vengeance rises like the morning sun.

ARMOR OF FATE

Between the sixteenth book and nineteenth verse,
A tragedy unfolds in measured time.
The substitute who wears another's face,
Patroclus, flame that burns too bright, too brief.

He drives the Trojans back from burning ships,
Sarpedon falls beneath his hungry spear,
But gods have marked the boundaries of men,
And three conspire to end his borrowed day.

The corpse contested like a kingdom's crown,
While messengers bear words that shatter peace.
Achilles' grief transforms to molten rage,
As Thetis seeks new armor from the forge.

Reconciliation comes with bitter taste,
As Agamemnon yields what pride had claimed.
The armies ready for the storm to come,
While Hector's doom approaches with the dawn.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'An account of books 16-19 of the Iliad by Homer.'

responses.text:
The Fields of Fate

Patroclus rises, clad in Achilles' armor,
A borrowed might to stem the Trojan tide.
The battlefield trembles beneath his fury,
As Hector's forces scatter far and wide.

Sixteen books deep, the war still rages on,
Greek ships aflame, their hopes nearly spent.
Patroclus, friend most dear, charges forth
To save his countrymen from dire lament.

In seventeen, Apollo strikes with godly hand,
Patroclus falls, stripped of divine disguise.
Hector claims the armor, pride swells his chest,
While Achilles' heart breaks as his brother dies.

Eighteen brings grief, a mother's gift of arms,
Forged by Hephaestus, god of sacred flame.
A shield that bears the cosmos in its face,
A weapon worthy of Achilles' name.

In nineteen, wrath gives way to something new:
Revenge, cold purpose, deadlier than before.
The hero rises, reconciled with kings,
To write his bloody signature on war.

ACHILLES' GRIEF

Between the burning ships and bloodied shore,
Where bronze-tipped spears sing death's approaching hymn,
Patroclus dons the armor not his own,
And charges forth on fate's precarious limb.

Book sixteen sees him fall by Hector's hand,
After Apollo's touch unsteadied him.
The borrowed armor stripped from cooling flesh,
A prize that makes Troy's future grimly dim.

In seventeen, they battle for his corpse,
Ajax and Menelaus stand their ground.
Like wolves protecting one fallen from their pack,
They fight until the body can be found.

The eighteenth book brings news to Thetis' son,
Achilles howls, his grief turns earth to stone.
His mother seeks new armor from the god
Whose forge can clothe a rage now fully grown.

By nineteen, feud with Agamemnon ends,
Briseis weeps between two broken men.
Achilles fasts but strengthens on his hate,
The poem's wheel turns toward its end again.

DIVINE MACHINATIONS

The gods look down from clouded peaks,
As mortal men in bronze-clad fury clash.
Patroclus leads, in borrowed glory dressed,
His fatal choice—a momentary flash.

Zeus watches as the Fates unwind their thread,
Apollo's hand upon the Trojan spear.
The archer-god strips armor from the man,
And Hector claims what victory holds dear.

A mother's tears fall silver in the deep,
As Thetis mourns what soon her son will know.
The battle for the corpse—a brutal dance,
As Greeks and Trojans trade both blood and blow.

Hephaestus labors through the starry night,
Creating shield and armor without peer.
Upon its face: the cosmos, life, and war,
A microcosm of what humans fear.

Achilles rises from his grief-struck tent,
Briseis returned, the kings now reconciled.
But peace between them heralds war for Troy,
As vengeance blooms where friendship once was filed.

The epic turns as gods pull mortal strings,
Their pawns advance across a blood-soaked board.
Books sixteen through nineteen—the pivot point,
Where fate's design cannot be long ignored.

SONGS OF BRONZE AND SORROW

When Patroclus donned the great Pelides' arms,
The sixteenth book unfolds with borrowed might.
He drives the Trojans back from blazing ships,
But gods have woven tragedy so tight.

Thrice nine he slays before Apollo strikes,
Stripping strength away with immortal hands.
Euphorbus wounds, then Hector deals death's blow,
As fate completes what destiny demands.

The seventeenth sings of battle for the dead,
Menelaus guards the fallen with his shield.
The son of Telamon, great Ajax, stands,
Refusing to abandon honor's field.

In eighteen, news arrives on grief's dark wings,
Achilles wails, his cries reach Nereid ears.
His mother Thetis seeks the Smith-God's aid,
For armor worthy of her son's fierce tears.

The shield he forges bears all earthly life—
War, peace, harvest, dance, and judgment scenes.
A cosmos carried into mortal strife,
To clothe the wrath that vengeance newly keens.

The nineteenth book sees kings at last make peace,
As Achilles hungers now for Hector's blood.
The die is cast, the final acts approach,
As Troy awaits war's crimson, fatal flood.

THE TURNING OF THE SPEAR

In bronze and blood the tale unfolds anew,
Where Book Sixteen sees Patroclus arise.
Borrowed armor gleaming in the sun,
A fatal choice that gods did not advise.

The Myrmidons like wolves upon the plain,
Drive Trojans back from ships nearly consumed.
But Zeus has set the boundary of his fate,
A life whose thread is already near-doomed.

Seventeenth canto: battle for the dead,
Ajax stands guard o'er Patroclus fallen.
Menelaus fights, Antilochus runs,
To bear black news to Peleus' grieving son.

In Eighteen, Thetis rises from the deep,
To comfort him whose wails shake heaven's gate.
The sea-nymph seeks divine Hephaestus' craft,
New armor for the vengeance that can't wait.

Upon the shield: two cities, peace and war,
The dance of stars, the harvest, and the law.
A universe encircled, art sublime,
To guard a heart that grief has rendered raw.

Book Nineteen: reconciliation comes,
As Agamemnon yields the girl at last.
But Achilles cannot taste of food or drink,
His hunger now for Hector's death held fast.
